author: Lauren Krugel
title: Suncor posts third-quarter loss of $376 million
description: Suncor says it can improve Syncrude performance with Canadian Oil Sands takeover
content:
Suncor Energy Inc. (TSX:SU) has posted a third-quarter net loss of $376 million, a sharp reversal from the $919-million profit from the same period a year earlier.
However, stripped of one-time items, Suncor eked out operating earnings of $410 million, down from $1.3 billion during the third quarter of 2014.
In the release announcing Suncor's third-quarter results late Wednesday, CEO Steve Williams said that if Suncor were able to increase its stake in the Syncrude oilsands mine, operations at the sprawling development north of Fort McMurray, Alta., would run more smoothly.
"We believe that we can drive real improvements in Syncrude's performance with a larger ownership interest," Williams said.
Earlier this month, the oilsands giant launched a hostile takeover bid for Canadian Oil Sands Ltd. (TSX:COS), whose main asset is a 37 per cent stake in Syncrude.
Suncor currently has a 12 per cent share of the mine, so a successful takeover would leave it owning just under half of it.
Canadian Oil Sands has rebuffed Suncor's advances, accusing the would-be acquirer of being exploitative and opportunistic.
Syncrude has been dogged by operational woes over the years. Most recently, a fire in late August damaged pipes, power and communication lines, leading to reduced output during the third quarter.
"We have been disappointed with Syncrude's performance for some time now," said Williams.
"The asset ran at only 67 per cent of capacity during the third quarter, and about 70 per cent so far this year, in stark contrast to Suncor's upgrading operations that have been consistently achieving above 90 per cent reliability this year."
Oil producers like Suncor have been squeezed by persistent weakness in crude prices, which have fallen to around $43 a barrel — down 60 per cent from the high point of last year.
During the third quarter, oilsands cash operating costs per barrel decreased to $27 — the lowest Suncor has seen since 2007 — from $31.10 a year earlier.
Overall production rose to 566,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day from 519,300.
"Our focus on operational discipline continues to pay off," said Williams.
"We're delivering on the reliability targets and cost reduction measures we established, leading to the lowest cash operating cost per barrel for oilsands operations in eight years — the results clearly demonstrate the impact this discipline has on Suncor's performance."
Canadian Oil Sands reports its earnings on Thursday afternoon.

title: Cameco looks to next-generation uranium enrichment
content:
Cameco Corp. is investing $123.8 million US to buy into the next generation of uranium enrichment, the company said Friday.
Saskatoon-based Cameco, which bills itself as the world's largest uranium producer, said the money will buy it a 24 per cent stake in Global Laser Enrichment (GLE), which is owned by General Electric and Hitachi.
GLE is working on a new uranium enrichment process using laser technology, which could be in commercial production in 2013, Cameco said.
Uranium enrichment is a key step in producing fuel for light water nuclear power plants. The deal extends Cameco's role in the process one more step, because it now does everything right up to the production of uranium hexafluoride, the form of uranium used in enrichment plants.
The demand for enriched uranium is expected to jump over the next decade as new nuclear power plants are built.
GLE has exclusive rights to develop and sell the laser technology worldwide, Cameco said.
The company also signed an agreement with GE Hitachi Nuclear Energy, the company which owns GLE,  to look into other nuclear business opportunities, such as selling uranium and enrichment services together as a bundle.
"Our businesses have potential synergies," said Jerry Grandey, Cameco's president and CEO.
Cameco stock rose 34 cents to settle at $37.90 on the TSX. The 52-week range is $31.39 to $58.32 Cdn.

title: Masonic Temple in Toronto sold to IT firm for $12.5M
description: Consultancy firm Info-Tech acquires historic building for its Toronto offices
content:
Toronto's storied Masonic Temple has found a new owner in an Ontario-based technology consulting firm after Bell Media (TSX:BCE) decided to sell the former concert hall earlier this year.
Info-Tech Research Group says it has paid $12.5-million for the historic building, which was most recently home to MTV Canada and previously hosted famous rock bands like the Rolling Stones and Led Zeppelin.
Info-Tech, which is headquartered in London, Ont., will renovate the downtown building to accommodate its Toronto satellite office.
Joel McLean, the company's president and CEO, says Info-Tech wanted a space that could house its employees, but also impress visitors from outside the country.
"We're consistently inviting company after company into Toronto (and) we wanted something that was spectacular to come see," he says.
"This spot not only offers an amazing space … but it's got great history."
The six-storey building on Toronto's Yonge Street has served as a concert hall that hosted famous musicians like Frank Sinatra. It was also a favourite rehearsal space for the Rolling Stones.
McLean says he will maintain the spirit of the entertainment era with meeting rooms named after some of the more famous musicians that played the Temple. He also plans to decorate the space with memorabilia that harkens back to the building's rock star days.
The firm says it will also keep the main concert hall's design so that it can move out office desks for its annual black-tie charity rock concert. In 2014, it plans to host, with its clients, an unofficial opening night party for the Toronto International Film Festival.
The Temple will initially house about 150 company employees, though McLean says the plan is to eventually increase that to 300 company staff.
Built for the Masons in 1918, the group sold the building to The Rosedale Group in 1996. The new owners pledged to reopen the hall and transform it into a centre for the arts, but a year later announced plans to tear it down and build condos on the site.
The Toronto Heritage Board fought back and it was sold to CTV in 1997, which utilized its cavernous spaces as television studios. The smaller rooms, hardly larger than walk-in closets, became video editing bays while other small spaces became storage areas for archive footage.
Through the years, the Masonic Temple was home of the late night talk show Open Mike with Mike Bullard and various other CTV-owned programs including eTalk Daily, Canadian Idol and TSN's Off The Record.
BCE Inc. took control of MTV in 2011 after it completed its $3.2-billion acquisition of CTV, bringing 29 specialty channels under its wing.
McLean says that buying the Masonic Temple serves more than one purpose, and perhaps design isn't the priority.
"Some of the space just isn't practical," he says.
"But as a research and consulting firm — and given who our staff are and who our members are — I'll take grand over practical any day."

title: Stock markets slide over VW scandal, commodity price swoon
description: TSX down 288, Dow loses 179, following lead of European stocks
content:
Markets took a hit on Tuesday from falling commodities prices and the widening scandal around Volkswagen's emissions fiddle.
The TSX and the Dow saw triple-digit falls, reversing gains they had made the previous day in the wake of the Fed announcement that interest rates would be unchanged for another month.
The Dow was down 179 points at 16,330 and the S&P 500 fell 24 points to 1,942.
Commodities prices were falling, with copper down nine cents to $2.30 US a pound and gold declining $8.37 to 1,125.07 US an ounce.
Oil is also waning, with the West Texas Intermediate contract down 85 cents to $45.83 US a barrel.
WTI crude rose four per cent yesterday, lifting it off lows below $45. It has maintained some of that gain, but today traders began to worry again about demand from China, where manufacturing data tomorrow may confirm an economic slowdown.
The Canadian dollar stayed lacklustre, slipping lower to 75.38 cents US.
But the biggest factor roiling markets has been the VW scandal, with the company admitting it cheated on emissions testing. That led to Volkswagen stock falling 34 per cent in the past two days. 
Other automakers were also pulled lower.
"Although VW may have lost a big chunk of its value, its shares could plunge even further if it is forced to pay a lot more than the 6.5 billion euros ($9.6 billion Cdn) it has set aside to handle the consequences of rigging U.S. emissions tests or if there are criminal charges for VW executives," said Fawad Razaqzada, an analyst at Forex.com.
"And things could turn really ugly if the probe expands to and finds other German carmakers guilty too."
Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks ended higher, but there were widespread losses in Europe, with Britain's FTSE 100 index of down 2.8 per cent at 5,935 and Germany's DAX down 3.8 per cent at 9,570.

A parallel scandal is unfolding in the drugs and biotech sector, where the news that companies were buying up drugs that are in the public domain and raising the price 2,000 to 5,000 per cent has provoked a political reaction.

Presidential candidate Hillary Clinton said she'd take steps to ensure that doesn't happen if she becomes president. That hurt biotech stocks.

title: Cott stock goes flat after Wal-Mart cuts shelf space
content:
Shares of Cott Corp. lost more than a third of their value Tuesday after the company disclosed that its largest customer planned to cut the bottler's shelf space.
Cott stock plunged $1.50 to close at $2.50 in trading on the TSX, a 38 per cent drop. The stock has traded as high as $19.70 in the past year.
Cott said it had "received notice of a reduction in shelf space and merchandising support for Wal-Mart's private label carbonated soft drinks in the U.S." in a news release issued Tuesday morning.
Wal-Mart is Cott's largest customer, and the retailer's change "would be significant to Cott's business plans."
Shelf space is vital for sales at large retailers, and any change can have a big impact on a supplier. 
But Cott also said it is still negotiating with Wal-Mart, "and Cott is fully committed to deploying the necessary efforts to maintain a mutually satisfactory relationship for the long term."
Cott said its announcement was a response to reports from undisclosed sources that Wal-Mart was thinking about cutting its shelf space. The stock, which slid 99 cents to $4 on Monday, had closed as high as $7 in mid-January.
Cott supplies more than 200 retailer and licensed brands. Its products include pop, waters, energy drinks, sports drinks, juices, juice drinks and smoothies and ready-to-drink teas.

title: Royal Bank to hike some mortgage rates starting Friday
description: RBC says its special offer 5-year fixed mortgage will go up one-tenth of a percentage point
content:
One of Canada's biggest lenders will be raising rates on several of its mortgages starting Friday.
Royal Bank of Canada says its special offer five-year fixed mortgage goes up one-tenth of a percentage point to 3.04 per cent.
It noted that the changes don't apply to its posted mortgage rates, which are typically higher than special offer rates.
Several other special offer mortgage rates from RBC will also rise by 0.10 per cent on Friday but the amount of annual interest charged will depend on whether the term is two, three or four years.
Royal (TSX:RY) is also raising the rate for a variable five-year mortgage by 0.15 per cent, starting Jan. 8.

author: Eric Anderson
title: Saskatchewan investors looking for clarity as market tumbles
description: Investment analyst says clients are confused by recent market declines
content:
When RBC investment advisor Rob Rongve picks up the phone in his North Battleford office, it's more confusion than panic he hears in the voices of his clients these days.
Last week's major losses on the North American and European markets, along with concerns in China, have left investors scratching their heads.
"People are calling and wanting to know what's going on and what's causing the volatility and declines in the market," Rongve said Monday.
Rongve noted that Friday was an especially brutal day for the markets. Monday morning, North American markets opened with the TSX and Dow Jones down more than 500 points.
Compounding that is the news of China's main index falling by more than eight per cent today. 
Rongve said it all adds up to be a scary start to the week.
"Panic is in the air so I would say to investors to hang tight today. It's probably too late to sell a lot of commodity-related names. It's a tough one if you need cash. You may want to look at selling some of your losers rather than your winners at this point."
The fall in commodities prices has particularly hurt investors in western Canada. The price of oil is below the $38-a-barrel level and Rongve said it's having an impact on local economies.
"We're hearing from our clients — in Alberta and Calgary particularly — that the layoffs are accelerating. It's going deeper than in the past as well," he added. 
Rongve doesn't see any rally in oil prices in the short term either.
In terms of how long this economic downturn will last, Rongve said there are situations investors can draw upon for optimism.
"You look back at 2008 and 2009 when the last great recession started and it was pretty bleak. But then it can turn on a dime and come back as well."
"As long as the U.S. is doing OK, they usually pull us up by the bootstraps and we'll all be ok," he added.

title: Bank of America to face charges for pre-recession mortgage sales
content:
Bank of America may be facing civil charges over mortgage backed securities and other mortgage-related matters.
The bank said in a regulatory filing Thursday that the Department of Justice told the company that it intends to file civil charges related to one or two jumbo-prime securitizations. The SEC is also considering filing civil charges against Merrill Lynch tied to a collateralized debt obligation investigation.
Banks used to regularly package mortgages into bundles known as CDOs, or collateralized debt obligations, and then sell them off in pieces to investors. Many went sour when the housing market collapsed.
Additionally, the filing said that the New York Attorney General's office intends to file action against Merrill Lynch, following an investigation of some of its residential mortgage backed securities.
Bank of America said that it is fully cooperating with the investigations. It also said that it has been in active discussions with each government entity in to explain why the threatened civil charges are not appropriate.
Company spokesman Lawrence Grayson said that the Bank of America has "made progress resolving many issues and will continue to work to address any outstanding matters."

title: AlarmForce ousts founder and CEO Joel Matlin
description: Founder and CEO 'terminated' as search for replacement begins
content:
AlarmForce Industries Inc. says it has "terminated" chief executive Joel Matlin after a strategic review of the company.
The home alarm company says it has started a search process to find a permanent replacement.
In the meantime, AlarmForce named chief financial officer Anthony Pizzonia as interim president and chief executive.
Matlin holds a nearly eight per cent stake in the company, according to data compiled by Thomson Reuters. He will continue to serve as a company director.
AlarmForce completed a nearly year-long strategic review, including a possible sale of the company, earlier this month without a deal.
The company said at the time it would focus on growing its business.

title: Teknion going private as controlling shareholder buys rest of company
content:
The controlling shareholder of office furniture maker Teknion Corp. isoffering to buyall of the company in a friendly deal worth$76.8 million.
An affiliate of A-Tean Holdings will pay $3.15 cash for each of the shares it doesn't already own. That's an 80 per cent premium over the $1.75 the shares closed at Friday on the TSX.
In morning TSX trading Monday, Teknion stock was up $1.28 to $3.03.
"The board of directors of Teknion (other than directors affiliated with A-Tean), upon the recommendation of the special committee, has unanimously approved the transaction and recommends that shareholders vote in favour of the transaction," the company said in a release Monday.
A shareholder vote will be scheduled for the first quarter of 2008. The deal is expected to close by April 15.
A-Tean Holdings and its affiliates own 62 per cent of the outstanding shares of Teknion.
In the year ended Nov. 30, 2006, Teknion reported annual sales of $631 million. In its most recent quarter, it turned a profit of $3.92 million.
Despite a strong Canadian dollar, the Toronto-based company has managed to post growing U.S. sales this year. Its American business accounts for almost 60 per cent of its revenue.

title: Chinese exports slump 3.1%
description: World's second-largest economy may be slowing its torrid pace of growth
content:
China's trade declined abruptly in June in a new sign of weakness in the world's second-largest economy.
Exports fell by 3.1 per cent compared with a year ago and imports contracted by 0.7 per cent, customs data showed. Both figures were below private sector forecasts of low single-digit growth.
China's economic expansion has slowed this year and is expected to slow further due to weak global demand and an effort by the Chinese central bank to cool a credit boom.
Analysts had expected China to report smaller trade figures due to a crackdown on misreporting of data by exporters as a way to evade currency controls and bring extra money into the country.
But even with that taken into account, Wednesday's falling figures were below forecasts that saw exports rising by up to 3.5 per cent and imports by up to 1.5 per cent.
June's numbers were down from 13.5 per cent growth in May and imports down from 8.2 per cent growth.
China's politically sensitive global trade surplus contracted by 12.4 per cent to $27.1 billion.
Growth in exports to the United States fell to 1.8 per cent while exports to Europe contracted 3.9 per cent.

title: Enerplus in friendly deal for Focus Energy Trust
content:
Enerplus Resources Fund said Monday it has struck a friendly deal worth about $1.22 billion to acquire Focus Energy Trust.
Enerplus is offering 0.425 of one of its units for each unit of Focus. Based on the closing price of Enerplus units on the Toronto Stock Exchange on Nov. 30, the offer values Focus at $17.38 a unit.
The two trusts said the offerincludes a premium of approximately three per cent over the 10-day weighted average price of Focus trust units on the TSX.
In TSX trading, units of Focus rose 48 cents to $16.60, while Enerplus was down almost three per cent to $39.75.
When the deal is done, Enerplus unitholders will own approximately 79 per cent and Focus unitholders will own approximately 21 per cent of the combined trust.
"This transaction provides our unitholders with increased exposure to oil, a greater diversity of resource plays, less asset concentration risk, a larger portfolio of more diverse organic drilling opportunities, increased tax pools and oilsands exposure," said Derek Evans, the president and chief executive officer of Focus, in a release.

title: Star Wars stuff is everywhere

title: IKEA founder Kamprad moving back to Sweden
description: Billionaire founder of furniture chain has been in Switzerland for past 30 years
content:
Ingvar Kamprad, founder of home furnishings company IKEA, is moving back to Sweden after more than 30 years in Switzerland.
Family spokesman Per Heggenes told The Associated Press on Wednesday that the 87-year-old will move "before the end of the year" to a farmhouse near his native Almhult, in southern Sweden.
Heggenes said Kamprad started thinking about moving when his wife died in 2011, and "decided to go back to Sweden to spend more time with his friends and his family."
He said Kamprad's three sons don't live in Sweden but spend their summer and Christmas vacations there.
The news was first reported by Swedish newspaper Sydsvenska Dagbladet.
Heggenes said Kamprad, who often appears on lists of the world's richest people, no longer has an operational role in the company.

title: Cinram units fall on 'likely' distribution cut
content:
Units of Cinram International Income Fund lost about nine per cent of their market value Monday, following a warning of a probable distribution cut.
The maker of pre-recorded DVDs and CDs saw its units fall $1.47 to close at $14.83 in heavy TSX trading.
Last Friday, TSX Market Surveillance directed an inquiry at the company, which had seen heavy trading in its units.
After the market closed, Cinram issued a statement that said it was "likely that a decision to cut distributions will be made at the trustees' meeting on November 5, 2007, at which time Cinram will issue a news release to formally communicate its decision." Cinram issues its third-quarter financial results after the markets close on Nov. 5.
Cinram's current annual distribution is $3.25(27.08 cents a month). During the most recent quarter, Cinram reported a net loss of $26.6 million and lower cash flows because oflower prices and a decline in DVD and CD unit volumes.

title: Alberta finance minister watching stock market swings
description: Dow Jones benchmark had its largest one-day drop on Monday
content:
Finance Minister Joe Ceci says he is keeping an eye on the swings in the stock market but says officials in his department aren't raising any alarms.
"No one has let me know at this point that there is a significant problem here, but it's something we're keeping a watch (on)," he said Tuesday.
In addition to the Heritage Savings Trust Fund, revenue generated by government investments through the Alberta Investment Management Corporation or AIMCO would be most exposed to volatility in the stock market.
On Monday, the benchmark Dow Jones industrial average had its largest one-day drop in history, losing 1,175 points, or 4.6 per cent, in one day of trading.
The Dow lost 500 points as soon as markets opened Tuesday but regained 76 points in midday trading.
Ceci said a huge percentage drop in the Dow would be of most concern to him.
Canadian shares have experienced seven straight days of decline. 
The S&P/TSX composite index in Toronto was lower Tuesday by 0.7 per cent at 15,222 points. 
The market was down 1.7 per cent at the close of trading Monday.

title: Medisys turns down CML takeover
content:
Units of Medisys Health Group Income Fund eased Friday, one day after the company rejected a takeover bid and said its controlling shareholder had cancelled a privatization.
Medisys slipped 84 cents, or 9.6per cent,to close at $7.90 on the TSX.
On Thursday, CML Healthcare Income Fund of Mississauga, Ont.,said it was offering $9 per share for Montreal-based Medisys. The Elman family, which controls 35 per cent of Medisys, had previouslylaunched a bid to buy the firm at $7 a share.
After the close of trading on Thursday, Medisys' board of trustees said it was advised by the Elman family that the CML offer was not acceptable. The family also said it was withdrawing its offer to buy all of the company.
The Medisys board told CML that talks regarding its offer are not warranted given that the Elman family is not on board.
CML said it needed to acquire two-thirds of Medisys' outstanding units, including those of Dr. Sheldon Elman, the chairman and CEO of Medisys, for its takeover to succeed.
CML HealthCare Income Fund operates CML HealthCare Inc., which owns two Ontario medical laboratories, 118 patient service clinics, and 104 medical imaging labs.
Medisys provides health-care and medical imaging services to corporations and individuals, and health-related underwriting support services to insurance companies.
CML units rose a penny to end at $16.01 on the TSX.

title: SNC-Lavalin fraud case with links to Libya put off until February
description: Proceedings were to have resumed in Montreal today but were put off until next year
content:
The criminal case against SNC-Lavalin for alleged fraud in Libya has been delayed until next February.
The RCMP allege the Montreal-based engineering giant paid nearly $47.7 million to public officials in Libya between 2001 and 2011 to influence government decisions.

Proceedings were to have resumed in Montreal today but were put off until Feb. 26.
The Mounties have also charged the company, its construction division and its SNC-Lavalin International subsidiary with one charge each of fraud and one of corruption for allegedly defrauding various Libyan organizations of about $129.8 million.
SNC (TSX:SNC) has previously said that it will plead not guilty and that the charges stem from alleged activities of former employees who face criminal charges.
If convicted, SNC-Lavalin could be banned from bidding on Canadian government contracts for 10 years under Ottawa's so-called integrity framework.

title: Thomson selling higher-learning division for $7.75B US
content:
Thomson Corp., which is eyeing the purchase of Reuters, got a large premium when it announced Friday it will sell its higher-education publishing business to Apax Partners and OMERS Capital Partners for $7.75 billion US.
Thomson had originally put the value of the publishing division at about $5 billion US.
The extra money will come in handy as Thomson is negotiating to buy Reuters Group in a deal that values the financial news and information provider at about $17.7 billion US.
Investors reactedby sending thecompany's shares up more than three per cent on both the TSX and the NYSE. The stock was $1.74 at $46.74 on the TSX, and up $1.46 US at $42.02 USin New York.
Thomson's higher-education publishing division includes Nelson Canada, Wadsworth, Delmar Learning, Gale, Heinle, Brooks/Cole and South-Western.
"This sale is part of Thomson's previously announced strategy to sell the assets of its Learning business to enable Thomson to pursue opportunities better aligned with its growth strategy and business model," the company said in a release.
As part of the transaction, OMERS will get majority ownership of Nelson Canada.
OMERS is the Ontario municipal employees' pension plan with about $48 billion in assets. OMERS Capital Partners oversees the pension plan's $2.5 billion in private equity assets.
Apax is a global private equity firm.

title: Saskatoon-based marijuana company launches $725M lawsuit over takeover bid
description: CanniMed Therapeutics fighting hostile takeover bid by Ontario company
content:
Saskatoon-based CanniMed Therapeutics Inc. has filed a lawsuit against Aurora Cannabis Inc., alleging what it calls "multiple claims of wrongdoing" related to Aurora's hostile bid to acquire the company.
In a statement released Friday evening, CanniMed (TSX:CMED) says it filed a lawsuit in Ontario Superior Court alleging Aurora and others conspired to injure CanniMed's economic interests.
CanniMed says it's also seeking personal damages against one current and one former member of its board for their alleged involvement in the purported conspiracy.
It says the action, which has not yet been served, seeks $725 million in damages.
The allegations have not been proven in court.
Aurora's chief corporate officer, Cam Battley, says CanniMed is "suing their own shareholders," adding that the company should never have gone public.
"Things are a mess over there," said Battley. "They should have remained private. By going public, they have exposed themselves to the realities and the discipline of the market."
Aurora also released a statement amending some aspects of its takeover bid, but made no mention of the lawsuit.
The new statement provides greater detail on how Aurora became aware that CanniMed's board would be meeting in November 2017 to consider acquiring Newstrike Resources Ltd.

title: Masonic Temple in Toronto sold to IT firm for $12.5M
description: Consultancy firm Info-Tech acquires historic building for its Toronto offices
content:
Toronto's storied Masonic Temple has found a new owner in an Ontario-based technology consulting firm after Bell Media (TSX:BCE) decided to sell the former concert hall earlier this year.
Info-Tech Research Group says it has paid $12.5-million for the historic building, which was most recently home to MTV Canada and previously hosted famous rock bands like the Rolling Stones and Led Zeppelin.
Info-Tech, which is headquartered in London, Ont., will renovate the downtown building to accommodate its Toronto satellite office.
Joel McLean, the company's president and CEO, says Info-Tech wanted a space that could house its employees, but also impress visitors from outside the country.
"We're consistently inviting company after company into Toronto (and) we wanted something that was spectacular to come see," he says.
"This spot not only offers an amazing space … but it's got great history."
The six-storey building on Toronto's Yonge Street has served as a concert hall that hosted famous musicians like Frank Sinatra. It was also a favourite rehearsal space for the Rolling Stones.
McLean says he will maintain the spirit of the entertainment era with meeting rooms named after some of the more famous musicians that played the Temple. He also plans to decorate the space with memorabilia that harkens back to the building's rock star days.
The firm says it will also keep the main concert hall's design so that it can move out office desks for its annual black-tie charity rock concert. In 2014, it plans to host, with its clients, an unofficial opening night party for the Toronto International Film Festival.
The Temple will initially house about 150 company employees, though McLean says the plan is to eventually increase that to 300 company staff.
Built for the Masons in 1918, the group sold the building to The Rosedale Group in 1996. The new owners pledged to reopen the hall and transform it into a centre for the arts, but a year later announced plans to tear it down and build condos on the site.
The Toronto Heritage Board fought back and it was sold to CTV in 1997, which utilized its cavernous spaces as television studios. The smaller rooms, hardly larger than walk-in closets, became video editing bays while other small spaces became storage areas for archive footage.
Through the years, the Masonic Temple was home of the late night talk show Open Mike with Mike Bullard and various other CTV-owned programs including eTalk Daily, Canadian Idol and TSN's Off The Record.
BCE Inc. took control of MTV in 2011 after it completed its $3.2-billion acquisition of CTV, bringing 29 specialty channels under its wing.
McLean says that buying the Masonic Temple serves more than one purpose, and perhaps design isn't the priority.
"Some of the space just isn't practical," he says.
"But as a research and consulting firm — and given who our staff are and who our members are — I'll take grand over practical any day."

title: Gold price on rebound after Fed calms rate fears
description: TSE gold stocks rally by 6% on the day
content:
Gold prices saw their biggest one-day gain in more than a year Monday after the U.S. Federal Reserve said last week it will continue to provide economic stimulus if needed.
The gold sector regained some lost ground, as the component rose about six per cent. The S&P/TSX composite index gained 73.25 points to 12,758.38 on top of four straight weeks of gains as traders also looked towards a busy earnings week for Canadian corporations
August bullion increased by $43.10 US to $1,336 US an ounce. That put it above $1,300 for first time in a month, and was the biggest one-day gain since June 2012.
"The fundamental reason is the backtracking by (Fed chairman Ben) Bernanke last week which was enough to remind everyone that there's TRIMs (trade-related investment measures) floating around and that's always good for the barbaric metal," said John Ing, president of Maison Placements in Toronto.
Ing says that all the talk of Detroit's bankruptcy, the possibility of banks getting out of commodities, debt going higher and the European crisis has reminded investors that after a hiatus in the spring, "the bad news... (is) back in time for the fall, so there's the uncertainty factor at work."
Gold prices had declined sharply in late May after Bernanke said the central bank could start tapering its monthly US$85 billion of bond purchases if economic conditions improved.
They started to revive last week, after he reiterated that the economy still needed stimulus. The TSX global gold sector had remained down 41 per cent year-to-date, but the price of gold was down only 20.2 per cent year-to-date after Monday's boost.
It had previously dropped by as much as 50 per cent, while the price of bullion fell 23 per cent so far in 2013.
Ing expects the increases in gold prices to continue for the near term, reaching $1,350 and then $1,550, as investors will once again turn to gold to protect themselves against an uncertain economic and political climate.
"I think we turned this corner very sharply, and of course we've seen this in the gold miners index — a lot of stocks are down 50 per cent from their highs. They've been beaten up, so a lot of them are up six, 10 per cent today," he said.
At the close Monday on the TSX:
A lower dollar also helped support commodity prices, as a weaker greenback made it less expensive for holders of other currencies to buy dollar-denominated oil and metals.

title: Husky Energy reports major gas leak, C-NLOPB says
content:
The regulator for the offshore oil industry in Newfoundland says Husky Energy (TSX:HSE) has reported a major hydrocarbon gas leak from a pipe linked to two of its subsea wells.
The Canada-Newfoundland and Labrador Offshore Petroleum Board says the gas release happened Monday in the southern drill centre in the White Rose Field.
It says Husky estimates that 8,938 kilograms of natural gas was released before it was shut off 12 minutes after the initial alarm.
Husky spokeswoman Colleen McConnell says an underwater inspection indicated the release came from a piece of flexible pipe connecting subsea components and leading into the wells.
She says it means there are limitations on the gas flow to the two wells, but they can still produce oil from the field.
The board is reviewing the incident and Husky is investigating.

title: Nucor makes $1.25B bid for Harris Steel
content:
Nucor Corp. on Tuesday made a friendly takeover bid for Harris Steel Group Inc. worth $1.25 billion Cdn.
Based in Charlotte, N.C., Nucor is offering $46.25 Cdn cash for Toronto-based Harris Steel.
John Harris, chairman and CEO of Harris Steel, along with other family members and company executives have already agreed to sell their shares. They collectively own over 13.7 million of the 27 million shares of Harris Steel that trade on the TSX.
"This transaction richly rewards the confidence our shareholders have placed in us," John Harris said in a release.
"This is a great day for our 3,000-plus employees who have helped create this shareholder value. In Nucor we have found a partner who shares our values, and will respect and nurture the unique culture that has enabled us to thrive," he said.
Shares of Harris Steel rose $2.55, or almost six per cent, to close at $46.04 on the TSX after the Nucor bid was announced.
Harris Steel makes concrete reinforcing steel, wire and heavy industrial steel grating, among other products.
Nucor is a steel recycler, and also fabricates steel in plants across the United States.

title: Caisse invests in Canadian and U.S. wind farms
description: Pension manager investing in Invenergy Wind
content:
Pension fund manager Caisse de depot et placement du Quebec has invested about $500 million US in wind farms in the United States and Canada owned by Invenergy Wind.
Chicago-based Invenergy said Tuesday that the portfolio of 11 operating wind farms in the United States and two in Canada have a combined output of about 1,500 megawatts.
One of the Canadian operations is the Le Plateau wind farm in Quebec's Gaspe region.
It has been in commercial operation since early 2012 and sells all of its renewable energy to Hydro-Quebec under a long-term contract.
Invenergy said it remains the majority controlling shareholder following the transaction.
Invenergy and its affiliated companies develop, own and operate large-scale renewable and other clean energy generation facilities in North America and Europe.

title: TMX takeover fight turns hostile
content:
A consortium of Canadian pension funds and banks is taking its hostile $3.6 billion bid directly to TMX Group shareholders after the stock exchange operator accelerated a shareholder vote on its favoured plan to merge with the London Stock Exchange.
The Maple Group Acquisition Corp. announced late Wednesday it will  soon mail shareholders its $48 per share proposal — which represents a 24 per cent premium to the implied value of the merger with the LSE Group.
The outcome of the battle between rival bidders for the TMX Group will determine the future of the  Canadian capital markets company, which runs the  Toronto Stock Exchange, the Montreal derivatives market and the junior TSX Venture Exchange.
The move by Maple Group to go directly to shareholders comes after the TMX Group formally rejected a proposal from the Canadian consortium last Friday, saying the bid breeds too many uncertainties, including regulatory and debt risks.
Earlier Wednesday, the TMX also said it would accelerate a shareholder vote on its proposed $3 billion US merger with the London Stock Exchange. Shareholders at both exchange companies are set to vote on their merger June 30.
"We are disappointed that the TMX board declined our repeated invitations to engage us in discussions. Had they done so, we are confident that we could have addressed any questions or concerns they might have regarding our superior proposal," said Maple Group spokesman Luc Bertrand, vice-chairman of National Bank.
"By choosing not to do so, and now by accelerating the timing of their meeting to consider the LSE take-over, they have given us no choice but to make our offer available directly to TMX Group shareholders."
He added that Maple Group still wants to speak directly with TMX's board of directors, if it decides to  negotiate. The TMX Group did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
The Maple group's bid must be accepted by 66 per cent of shareholders. The Maple g bid, announced earlier this month, is meant to keep TMX in Canadian ownership after many bank and government officials raised concerns about the so-called "merger of equals" with the LSE, which is technically a takeover by the British operator.
But the TMX Group is intent on pushing ahead with the London Stock Exchange transaction. The deal is subject to approval from various Canadian regulators, including a review from Industry Canada under the Investment Canada Act, which must determine if the merger is "of net benefit" to Canada. 
However, the Maple bid is not without its own regulatory challenges.
It is dependent on a review by the Competition Bureau, which must rule whether the group can go ahead with plans to acquire the bank-owned alternative stock exchange Alpha Group and the CDS clearinghouse.
Any integration of the operator of the Toronto Stock Exchange and the alternative Alpha trading platform would give the group control of about 80 per cent of stock trading volume in Canada.
Bertrand said the group will begin the regulatory process "shortly," adding that he is confident that it can obtain all the required shareholder and regulatory approvals to close the deal by late fall.
Members of the Maple Group Acquisition Corp. include Alberta Investment Management Corp., Caisse de depot et placement du Quebec, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, CIBC World Markets Inc., Fonds de solidarite des travailleurs du Quebec, National Bank Financial Inc., Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board, Scotia Capital Inc. and TD Securities Inc.

title: Dow closes above 12,000 for first time
content:
The Dow Jones industrial average has closed above the 12,000 level for the first time in its history.
The world's best-known market index gained 19.05 points on Thursday to end the trading day at 12,011.73.
Year-to-date, the Dow is up12.1 per cent. A big part of that increase is due to General Motors, one of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow. GM shares are up 70 per cent this year, after taking a big tumble last year.
A broader measure of the U.S. market — the S&P 500 index — is up 9.5 per cent so far this year.
The S&P/TSX composite index also finished above 12,000, but that's territory it's seen before.
Toronto's benchmark index rose 94.62 points to close at 12,060.62. Its record high was set Apr. 19, 2006, when it touched 12,494.
The Toronto market's strength on Thursday came from a 3.2-per-cent rise in the gold group and a 1.8-per-cent increase among oil and gas stocks.
Gold prices gained more than $10 US an ounce to $599 US. Crude oil futures rose 85 cents US to $58.50 US a barrel.
Since the start of the year, the S&P/TSX composite has risen seven per cent.

title: Most Canadian equity mutual funds fail to beat the market: S&P
content:
The majority of actively-managed Canadian equity mutual funds have lagged the market as a whole this year, Standard & Poor's said Thursday.
The financial company said fewer than one in five (18.8 per cent) of actively-managed Canadian funds outperformed the S&P/TSX composite index in the first half of the year.
Among U.S. equity funds, the performance recordimproved. But more than 61 per cent of them still couldn't beat theU.S. benchmark index—the S&P 500.
Active management refers to funds where managers make the decisions about what stocks to buy or sell. In passively-managed funds,thefunds are designed to automatically track a particular index.
"Active managers are having a hard time in this year's volatile markets," said Standard & Poor's Jasmit Bhandal, in astatement.
Over the last five years, the record of underperformance has been even more pronounced. Standard & Poor's said only 13.9 per cent of Canadian equity funds have outperformed the S&P/TSX composite index.
In the same time span, about a quarter of actively-managed U.S. equity funds have beaten the S&P 500 index.
Small-cap managers more successful in beating market
Managers of Canadian small-cap equity funds have had more success, S&P said. In the first six months of 2006, almost half of Canadian small-cap funds managed to beat the S&P/TSX Small Cap Index. And in several quartersbefore 2006, a majority of small-cap managers beat the relevant index.
One big reason why actively-managed funds often fail to beat the market has to do with the fees charged to the fund. Actively-managed funds are more expensive to run than passive ones. The various fees and expenses — often two to three per cent of the fund's value — are deducted before returns are calculated.
So active managers must, in effect, beat the market by that two or three per cent just to break even. That's difficult to consistently do, although some fund managers areable to do it.
Exchange-traded funds and index funds— which are designed to track a particular index— won't ever beat the market. But they do provide similar diversification at a fraction of the fees that actively-managed funds charge.
Supporters of active management point out that theirfeesare used, in part, to compensatefinancial planners and advisors for the ongoing service of their clients' accounts.

title: Bell won't sell more of Astral's assets to win OK for merger
description: Astral Media CEO says impact would be 'severe' if CRTC denies Bell's pitch
content:
Bell would walk away from buying Astral Media if it's asked to sell any more of the TV specialty and radio company's assets in order to win regulatory approval for the $3.4-billion merger, chief executive George Cope said Friday.
Cope said there wouldn't be any "strategic rationale" to buy Astral if it had to sell more of its assets to obtain the OK from the CRTC, which has already turned down the deal once.
"If we were to be asked to divest any more of the channels or content, we would not move forward with the transaction," Cope said.
Rogers Communications (TSX:RCI.B) has asked the CRTC to force Bell to sell Astral's English language pay TV service, the Movie Network, as a condition of approving the revised deal. Rogers has told the CRTC it would then take a look at buying the Movie Network itself.
Bell said it wouldn't be able to make its strategy of more content available on multiple platforms and more competition work if forced to sell more of Astral's assets.
"From our perspective, additional divestitures from what we're doing now we don't believe we can materially executive the strategy for this size of acquisition," he said. "The strategic rationale for the acquisition would not be there."
Astral CEO Ian Greenberg said the consequences for his company would be severe if the CRTC doesn't approve the deal the second time round. He noted Astral is a family owned company and there are four families involved in the sale of the Montreal company.
"We have to remember for the last 15 months our employees and the business have had to cope with the distraction and the uncertainty associated with the sale of a company," he said.
"Obviously, if it was denied I would have to address the situation with my family," he said. "Obviously what this would do is extend the uncertainty for our people and our business for at least another year and I think that would be a disservice to the industry and a disservice to our employees and to our shareholders. It would be quite severe."
The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission turned down the deal last fall, saying it wasn't in the best interests of Canadians.
Bell (TSX:BCE) is making its final pitch to the CRTC to buy Astral (TSX:ACM.A), and it's revised proposal would, among other things, see Bell sell all of Astral's English language specialty services and one of its English pay TV services. However, it would keep eight of Astral's channels including the pay TV service, The Movie Network.

title: Shoppers Drug Mart makes friendly bid for MediSystem
content:
Shoppers Drug Mart Co. said Friday it has struck a friendly deal to buy MediSystem Technologies Inc. for roughly $89.9 million.
Based in Toronto, MediSystem provides pharmaceutical products and services to long-term care facilities in Ontario and Alberta.
Shoppers has agreed to pay $3.80 in cash per MediSystem share or the equivalent of $3.75 in Shoppers common shares plus five cents in cash per MediSystem share. MediSystem shareholders will able to choose to receive cash, Shoppers common shares or a combination of cash and Shoppers stock.
MediSystem management has endorsed the takeover bid and is recommending that shareholders accept it.
"We are extremely pleased to have delivered this exceptional offer to our shareholders," said Gary Chin, MediSystem's president and chief executive officer. "This offer represents a major commitment by Shoppers to the long-term care market in Canada."
The companies said the offer represents a premium of almost 27 per cent on the July 28 closing price of MediSystem's shares on the TSX.
In the wake of the offer, MediSystem shares were up 74 cents, or more than 25 per cent, at $3.74on the TSX. Shoppers' shares were off 19 cents at $44.44.

title: Vancouver's Russell Breweries gets takeover offer
description: Premier Diversified Holdings takes minority stake but wants 51%
content:
Vancouver's Russell Breweries is the target of a takeover offer from Premier Diversified Holdings Inc., which recently acquired a significant minority stake in the regional beer maker.
Premier says it would exchange one of its common shares for every 2.5 shares of Russell, which is headquartered near Vancouver in Surrey, B.C.
Russell shares closed at six cents per share on the TSX Venture Exchange and Premier's closed at 17 cents on the over-the-counter market.
Premier says it currently owns 16.7 per cent of Russell's outstanding shares and has a lockup agreement for another 2.29 per cent.
It's seeking to buy up to 51 per cent of Russell's shares but doesn't plan to change its business or acquire full ownership.

title: Valkyries Petroleum agrees to takeover by Lundin
content:
Shares of junior energy firm Valkyries Petroleum Corp. jumpedMonday after the company said it has reached a deal to be acquired by Sweden's Lundin Petroleum Corp
The all-share deal is valued at roughly $780 million.
In the wake of the announcement, Valkyries' shares jump more than 15 per cent to $14.40 on the TSX Venture Exchange in morning trading.
Under the terms of the deal, Valkyries' shareholders will receive one Lundin share for each Valkyries common share held.
Vancouver-based Valkyries' main assets include interests in developing oil and gas projects in Russia, including:
Valkyriesrecently entered into a binding agreement to purchase a 50-per-cent interest in the producing North Irael field, located in the Komi Republic.
"This transaction creates a new core area for Lundin Petroleum in Russia," said Ashley Heppenstall, the president and chief executive of Lundin.
The Swedish company has oil and gas assets in Albania, France, Indonesia, Ireland, Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Sudan, Tunisia, United Kingdom and Venezuela.
Shares of Valkyries rose$1.49, or almost 12 per cent, to finish at $14 on the TSX Venture Exchange.

title: New Stelco shares jump in first day of trading
content:
Stelco's new shares were a hot commodity on the TSX in their first day of trading on Monday as the steelmaker completed a painful restructuring following more than two years in bankruptcy protection. 
The shares, which are listed under the trading symbol STE (TSX:STE), were issued at $5.50. They opened trading at $15 and closed at $19.49. 
More than two-thirds of the new Stelco shares are held by restructuring fund Tricap Management Ltd. and investment firms Sunrise Partners LP of Toronto and Appaloosa Management LP of New York. 
They are providing hundreds of millions of dollars in loans to finance badly needed upgrades at Stelco's facilities. 
The province of Ontario also kicked in a $150-million forgivable loan. 
Stelco's old shares were delisted from the TSX on March 10, losing all their value as holders of its common stock were left out of the restructuring. 
New Stelco faces major challenges 
The embattled steelmaker emerged from creditor protection on the weekend. However, It still faces an uncertain future due to weak steel prices and major competitive and productivity pressures. 
Stelco's new CEO, Rodney Mott, was formerly the chief executive at International Steel Group in Ohio, which was bought by Mittal Steel last year. With Mott's arrival, former CEO Courtney Pratt became Stelco's chairman. 
Mott bought 1 million shares at $5.50 each â an investment that returned him a quick profit of almost $14 million, at least on paper. He also has been granted options on 1.04 million more shares at $5.50 each. 
One of Mott's first major challenges will be to negotiate a new collective agreement with Stelco workers at its Hilton Works facility in Hamilton, Ont. Stelco says its Hamilton operations are not competitive. 
Stelco's rebirth comes 26 months after it filed for creditor protection. What followed was one of the most convoluted, expensive, and unusual restructurings in Canadian corporate history. 
The restructuring was unusual because steel prices rebounded strongly after the creditor protection filing, leading to big profits at a company that had been losing money. 
The good times weren't to last, however. Steel prices were falling again by 2005, and the company posted a $120-million loss in its most recent quarter. 
Stelco ended up selling several subsidiaries and shedding 1,500 workers. Debt holders had to settle for 66 cents on the dollar and former shareholders were wiped out. 
Many analysts believe a larger company may try to acquire Stelco. The steel industry has seen enormous consolidation in the last year.

title: CV Technologies' Cold-fX cleared for sale in United States
content:
The shares of CV Technologies Inc. shot up on Monday after the company said it had won clearance to sell its Cold-fX cold and flu drug in the United States. 
The Edmonton-based company expects the drug will be available for sale in the U.S. in time for the cold and flu season in the fall of 2006. 
CV Technologies shares (TSX:CVQ) were up almost 25 per cent on the TSX, closing at $3.36. 
The patented active ingredient in Cold-fX has been accepted by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration as a new dietary ingredient, the company said. 
"We are pleased that this significant milestone has been achieved and that our board of directors has given its support to proceed with management's U.S. launch plans," said Dr. Jacqueline Shan, CV Technologies' president, chief executive officer and chief scientific officer. 
"We have been working on strategies for the past nine months and we now look forward to executing them," Shan said. 
Promoted by hockey commentator Don Cherry, Cold-fX is the bestselling cold and flu remedy in Canada, CV Technologies claims. 
It is made from chemicals found in North American ginseng. The company has been licensed by Health Canada as a manufacturer of natural health products after clinical testing showed the drug was effective in combatting the common cold. 
The company claims that Cold-fX strengthens the immune system.
