title: Yellow Pages buys Trader Canada for $760M
content:
Yellow Pages Group said Monday it is buying Classified Media (Canada) Holdings Inc., which is also known as Trader Canada, for $760 million in cash. 
Trader Canada publishes 137 publications and nine websites covering three main areas â automotive, real estate and general merchandise. Its main brands include Auto Trader, Auto Hebdo, The Bargain Finder and Home Renters' Guide. 
Trader Canada accounts for roughly 36 per cent of the revenue of the seller, Trader Classified Media N.V. 
In December 2005, Yellow Pages bought Trader Media Corp., which covers the Ontario market, for $436 million. 
"The acquisition of Trader Canada represents the critical step in the creation of a national platform for verticals following the acquisition of [Trader Media Corp.] earlier this year," said Marc Tellier, the president and CEO of Yellow Pages. 
He said the combination of Trader Canada and Trader Media Corp. (TMC) will give Yellow Pages a national presence with more than 200 publications and 20 websites. 
The combination of Trader Canada and TMC generated revenues of approximately $297.5 million and adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, dividends and amortization of $90.9 million last year. 
Yellow Pages Group is 96 per cent owned by Yellow Pages Income Fund (TSX:YLO.un) . 
Units of Yellow Pages fell 45 cents to close at $16 on the TSX.

title: Focus Energy Trust buying Profico Energy in $1.2B deal
content:
Focus Energy Trust said Monday it has struck a merger deal worth $1.2 billion with privately held natural gas company Profico Energy Management. 
Calgary-based Focus will issue 31 million trust units, 10 million limited partnership units — which are exchangeable one-for-one for trust units — and pay $92.8 million in cash to Profico shareholders. Focus will assume approximately $87.2 million of Profico's net debt. 
When the deal is completed, shareholders of Profico will own approximately 51 per cent of the Focus trust units (TSX:FET.un) , on a fully diluted basis. 
Focus will pick up Profico's Shackleton and Southwest Saskatchewan properties, which produce approximately 14,500 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
"We are excited to add Profico's high quality assets to our portfolio," Derek Evans, the president and CEO of Focus, said in a statement. 
The deal is expected to close after shareholder meetings in late June 2006. 
The boards of directors of the two companies have agreed that they will not solicit discussions or negotiations with any other parties, and have agreed to a breakup fee of up to $40 million. 
Units of Focus rose by 75 cents to close at $25.89 on the TSX.

title: CHUM stock rises on profit report
content:
A big jump in television profits sparked a sharp increase in the share price of broadcaster CHUM Ltd. on Thursday. 
Before the market opened, the company reported that profit had more than doubled in the three months ended Feb. 28. 
CHUM stock (TSX:CHM.NV.B) jumped more than seven per cent or $2.05 to $31.05 on the TSX. 
Profit before financial charges and tax at CHUM's 33 TV stations was up 45 per cent to $14.8 million from $10.2 million. At the radio division, which also has 33 stations, there was a 2.7-per-cent increase to $8.7 million. 
Corus, also a TV and radio company, reported strong TV results but a debt charge produced an overall loss. 


CHUM said profit for the three months ended Feb. 28 was $5.9 million (21 cents a share), compared with $2.5 million (nine cents) a year earlier. 
Revenue was $152.4 million, compared with $141.3 million. 
Profit for the six months ended Feb. 28 was $30.2 million ($1.07 a share), compared with $24 million (87 cents) a year earlier. 
Revenue was $339.2 million, compared with $301.9 million.

title: U.S. parent firm claims success in Sears Canada takeover
content:
The U.S. parent company of Sears Canada claimed victory on Thursday in its bid to take the subsidiary private. 
Sears Holdings Corp. (NASDAQ:SHLD) of Hoffman Estates, Illinois, said it now has a majority of the common shares of Sears Canada (TSX:SCC) it did not own prior to launching its takeover bid. 
"Accordingly, Sears Holdings and its affiliates will own or have support commitments for sufficient shares to assure the necessary shareholder approval of a going private transaction of Sears Canada at the offer price of $18.00 per share," the company said. 
The announcement came just one day after Sears Holdings said $18 per share for Sears Canada was its final offer. The U.S. parent firm boosted its offer to $18 on April 3 from the original bid of $16.86 per share. 


Sears Holdings said it has now extended its takeover bid to August 31. 
Shares of Sears Canada closed at $18.50 on Thursday, down 9 cents from its previous close on the TSX.

title: Vincor agrees to $1.52B takeover offer from Constellation Brands
content:
Five months after spurning a previous takeover attempt, Canada's Vincor International has accepted a $1.52-billion all-cash takeover offer from U.S. liquor giant Constellation Brands. 
Constellation will pay $36.50 a share for Vincor stock (TSX:VN) plus the assumption of about $250 million in debt.. That's a 15.9-per-cent premium to Vincor's closing price of $31.50 last Friday. 
Vincor shares closed at $36.25 in heavy Monday trading on the TSX â up more than 15 per cent on the day. 
The boards of both companies have recommended the deal's acceptance. 
"We are pleased that Constellation has offered a value that fully recognizes our strong brands, exceptional workforce and significant international growth opportunities," Vincor chief executive Donald Triggs said in a release. 
Last November, Vincor formally rejected a hostile $33-a-share offer from Constellation as "inadequate." Shareholders acted similarly and rejected the Constellation offer in December. 


The deal requires the apporval of two-thirds of Vincor shareholders at a meeting set for June 1. 
Constellation's wine brands include Woodbridge by Robert Mondavi, Inglenook, Paul Masson, Hardys and Banrock Station. Its best known liquor brand is Black Velvet. 
Mississauga, Ont.-based Vincor's brands include Inniskillin and Jackson-Triggs. Vincor is Canada's biggest wine producer.

title: Skor Foods buys 11 wholesale outlets from Sobeys
content:
The Skor Food Group Inc. said Friday it has acquired 11 cash and carry wholesale locations in southern Ontario from Sobeys Inc. 
The outlets operate under the Lumsden Brothers banner. 
Skor, which is based in Mississauga, Ont., said the acquisition will boost its yearly revenue to $260 million. The company's stated goal is to eventually grow to $500 million in revenue. 
Based in Stellarton, N.S., Sobeys (TSX:SBY) said it is closing its three remaining cash and carry outlets in Ontario and Quebec. 
"The sale and closures are consistent with the company's stated focus on its core food retailing and distribution business and will be accretive to future earnings," Sobeys said in a release. 
The company said the disposal will result in a pre-tax cost of $1.5 million on Sobeys' 2006 earnings but will contribute to an improvement in its annual earnings. 
Sobeys owns or franchises more than 1,300 stores in all 10 provinces under retail banners that include Sobeys, IGA extra, IGA and Price Chopper. 
Shares of Sobeys slipped 5 cents to close at $37.75 on the TSX.

title: Le Chateau may put itself on the auction block
content:
Clothing retailer Le Chateau Inc. will consider proposals for a merger or the outright sale of its business, the company said Tuesday. 
In a statement released before the opening of stock markets, the Montreal-based company said it is evaluating strategic alternatives, including the sale of the company, a merger or a capital reorganization. 
Le Chateau has hired Genuity Capital Markets as its financial adviser. It said the evaluation process could take several months. 
"This step is a natural and logical part of our evolution and growth and we believe that this is the right time to review such opportunities in the best interest of Le Chateau and all of its shareholders," said company chairman and CEO Herschel Segal. 
Le Chateau has 180 retail locations in Canada, and five more in the New York City area. 
Over the past year, shares of Le Chateau have ranged from a low of $24.71 to a high of $55.75 on the TSX. 
The stock was up more than 12 per cent Tuesday on the TSX, gaining $5.95 to reach $53.85.

title: CIBC to acquire majority control of FirstCaribbean bank
content:
CIBC said Monday that it will buy majority control of FirstCaribbean International Bank in a $1.08 billion US deal with Barclays Bank PLC. 
CIBC (TSX:CM) said it has signed a non-binding agreement to buy Barclays' 43.7 per cent stake in FirstCaribbean at $1.62 US per share. The deal would give CIBC an 87.4 per cent stake in FirstCaribbean. 
With more than $9.6 billion US in assets, FirstCaribbean is the largest regionally listed bank in the English-speaking Caribbean. The bank has more than 100 outlets and offices in 17 countries in the region. 
CIBC acquired its initial 43.7 per cent stake in FirstCaribbean when its operations in the region were merged with those of Barclays in 2002 to form FirstCaribbean. 
The deal is expected to be completed by late 2006, CIBC said. 
"With its established retail, wealth management, corporate and capital markets businesses, FirstCaribbean is an excellent fit for CIBC and is well-positioned for long-term success in a region that we believe has attractive growth prospects," Gerry McCaughey, CIBC's president and CEO, said in a statement. 
Shares of CIBC slipped 62 cents to close at $83.78 on the TSX.

title: Deal bulks up rent-a-guard empire
content:
Montreal-based Garda World Security, a giant among Canadian security-guard contractors, says it has bought one of its rivals, Rentokil Initial Canada. 
The firm said it swung the approximately $60-million deal with loans from BMO Nesbitt Burns and Quebec's $102-billion public pension-fund manager, the Caisse de dÃ©pÃ´t et placement. 
Garda's share price (TSX:GW) spiked as much as 11 per cent higher, touching a new peak of $24.45, after the announcement on Friday. 
It closed up 7.2 per cent or $1.57 at $23.49 in TSX trading. 
The acquired operation, better known as Initial Security, was a unit of Britain's Rentokil Initial, whose diverse interests include office cleaning, courier services and pest control as well as security. Based in Edmonton, Initial offers such services as "uniformed protection, labour unrest protection and mobile patrol," Garda said. 
"Strategically, this acquisition is an excellent complement to our current physical security operations as it creates the critical mass in several major markets in Western Canada and in Ontario," Garda CEO Stephan Cretier said in a statement. 


Garda, which already had more than 14,000 employees, including security guards, investigators and armoured-car crews, said the deal will expand its payroll to more than 19,000 in 60 branches, and its annual revenues to about $600 million. It will take about six months to merge the two operations, the company said.

title: Canada falling behind on women on corporate boards
content:
Canada is falling behind other countries when it comes to putting women on corporate boards, according to a report by TD Economics.
While participation in the labour force has increased significantly for women, that change has yet to be reflected at the top of Canada's largest companies, according to the report.
Women represent just 11 per cent of board members on companies listed on the S&P/TSX composite index, which represents large publicly traded Canadian companies.
Women have much larger representations on the boards of foreign companies listed on many major worldwide stock markets.
Among the TSX-composite-listed companies, 42 per cent have no women on the boards of directors, while 28 per cent had just one female board member.
The TD report's 11-per-cent figure is slightly lower than that of a similar survey by GMI Ratings, which puts the percentage of female board members at 13.1 per cent. GMI's survey looked at fewer companies than TD's report, which may account for the difference.
According to GMI Ratings, Canada ranked 9th among major industrialized nations for female board membership in 2011. That's down from 6th place in 2009.

United States: 12.6% 
Source: GMI ratings
The decline has a number of implications, according to Beata Caranci, deputy chief economist at TD and lead author on the report.
"First, it is simply an unacceptable outcome on equity grounds. Second, and more troubling to economists, it implies a market failure to appreciate the skills and perspectives that women can bring to the table."
What the report doesn't call for is for quotas for women on boards, similar to what exists in countries like Norway and the United Arab Emirates.
"They are the antithesis of merit," writes Caranci. "They also risk stigmatizing qualified women on boards as 'tokens'." 
Instead, the report calls for a tough new "comply or explain" policy, which would require companies to put gender diversity policies in place when it comes to choosing new board members. It would allow companies to ignore those policies, but only if they explain why to shareholders.
It also calls for companies to disclose the proportion of board members and senior executives that are female, so progress can be measured. The report says this would increase transparency, awareness and accountability on gender diversity.
While the number of women on boards at Canadian companies is falling behind, the number of women at the top of major Canadian companies is even lower.
None of the S&P/TSX 60 companies — the 60 largest publicly traded companies in Canada — have female CEOs. Only two, BlackBerry and Manulife, have boards of directors chaired by women.
Notable female CEOs in Canada include Linda Hasenfratz, head of auto parts manufacturer Linamar, Christine Day, CEO of Lululemon Athletica, and Heather Reisman, CEO of Indigo Books & Music.

title: Agrium picks up Royster-Clark for $616M
content:
Feed and fertilizer giant Agrium Inc. has won its bid for U.S. rival Royster-Clark Ltd., making Agrium the largest agricultural retailer in the United States. 
Calgary-based Agrium will pay $11.90 a unit for Royster-Clark's Income Deposit Securities. 
Royster-Clark's shareholders tendered 98.6 per cent of their shares by Agrium's deadline on Wednesday, for a total purchase price of about $616 million. 
"We are very pleased to have concluded this accretive acquisition and will immediately start the integration process in order to provide a smooth transition for our new employees and customers," Agrium CEO Mike Wilson said in a release Thursday morning. 
"As the new industry leader in direct-to-grower agricultural retail sales, we are confident that we can create significant value for our customers, shareholders and employees." 
Agrium said it intends to acquire the remaining common shares of Royster-Clark, as allowed under Ontario law. 
Agrium is a major Canadian dealer in seed, chemicals and fertilizer. 
Virginia-based Royster-Clark is a U.S. retail distributor of agricultural nutrients, seed and crop protection products, and provider of farm services to U.S. growers, with about $1.15 billion US in sales last year. 
Agrium (TSX:AGU)rose 25 cents in early trading Thursday, to $27.75. 
Royster-Clark (TSX:ROY.UN)fell three cents in early trading Thursday, to $11.82, just off the 52-week high of $11.94. 
Both companies trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CN shares surge on rosy corporate news
content:
Shares of Canadian National Railway soared almost $5 Wednesday after it reported better-than-expected profits and announced a dividend boost and stock split. 
CN stock (TSX:CNR) was up $4.91 to close at $101.24 on the TSX, hitting a new 52-week high. 
After the markets closed Tuesday, CN announced fourth-quarter profits of $430 million ($1.56 a share), up 14 per cent from last year's $376 million ($1.29 a share). That was 2 cents better than the consensus estimate from 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson One Analytics. 
Operating income in the quarter rose 19 per cent to $720 million and revenues climbed 9 per cent to $1.89 billion. 
"All the pieces came together â stronger pricing, gains from our acquisitions, and solid returns from good service, cost control and improved productivity," said CNR chief executive E. Hunter Harrison in a release. 
In a separate announcement, CN also announced a 30 per cent increase in its quarterly dividend to 16.25 cents per share and said it would split its stock two-for-one at the end of February. 
This would be the third stock split and the 10th dividend increase that Canada's largest railway has announced since 1995.

title: ThyssenKrupp drops out of Dofasco bidding
content:
Dofasco Inc.'s white knight, ThyssenKrupp AG of Germany, has dropped out of the bidding war for the Hamilton-based steelmaker. 
ThyssenKrupp announced after financial markets closed Monday that its executive board had decided not to raise its offer beyond $68 per share, saying to do so "would go beyond the point of creating economic value." 
Bidding rival Arcelor SA of Luxembourg boosted its offer for Dofasco last week to $71 a share, making the bid worth $5.5 billion. ThyssenKrupp had until midnight Monday to match it. 
Late Monday, Dofasco terminated its agreement to support ThyssenKrupp's bid, meaning a $215-million break-up fee is now payable by Dofasco to the German company when its offer officially expires Jan. 26. 




Shares of Dofasco (TSX:DFS) closed down $1.10 at $71.90 on the TSX.

title: Fairmont rejects Carl Icahn bid
content:
Fairmont Hotels & Resorts Inc. has formally turned down a bid by U.S billionaire financier Carl Icahn to buy majority control of the company. 
Fairmont said Icahn's $40 US per share bid for 41 per cent of the hotel chain was too low and "not in the best interest of Fairmont or its shareholders." 


The hotel chain's board of directors called on shareholders to reject Icahn's offer. 
In early November, Icahn announced he had paid $185 million US to acquire a 9.3 per cent of Fairmont's stock, saying he wanted the Canadian-based luxury hotel chain to take steps to boost the company's "undervalued" share price. 


Fairmont (TSX:FHR) owns or operates more than 80 properties around the world, including the Chateau Laurier in Ottawa, the Queen Elizabeth in Montreal, the Newfoundland in St. John's, the Royal York in Toronto, Chateau Lake Louise and the Banff Springs Hotel in Alberta, the Hotel Vancouver and Victoria's Empress. 
Fairmont also owns Delta hotels in Canada. 
Shares of Fairmont rose $1.14 to $47.78 on the TSX.

title: Yellow Pages buying AutoTrader publisher for $436M
content:
Yellow Pages Group said Monday it is buying Trader Media Corp. for $436 million in cash and equity. 
Currently owned by Fraser Francis Ltd., Trader Media has over 65 publications and websites, including the used vehicle classified ad magazine AutoTrader, and several real estate magazines such as Renters News, Resale Homes and New Homes & Condos. Trader Media's main market is in Ontario. 
Yellow Pages Group said it will acquire the publishing company for $135 million in cash and $301 million worth of exchangeable units. Those units are eligible to be converted into units of Yellow Pages Income Fund (TSX:YLO.un). The units amount to a four per cent ownership stake in the income fund. 
Yellow Pages said Trader Media generates about $133 million in annual revenues and $43 million in pre-tax operating profits. 
Trader Media "brings significant value to YPG to help us continue to grow in the advertising market," said Yellow Pages CEO Marc Tellier. 
Founded in 1975, Trader Media employs about 775 people. 
Units of Yellow Pages Income Fund were up 63 cents at $16.38 on the TSX.

title: Scotiabank expands presence in Peru
content:
Bank of Nova Scotia plans to invest $330 million US to expand its presence in the banking industry in Peru. 
In an announcement issued late Monday, Scotiabank (TSX:BNS) said it will acquire 80 per cent of Banco Wiese Sudameris from Banca Intesa of Italy. Scotiabank will also acquire majority control of Banco Sudamericano. It already owns 35 per cent. 
The two Peruvian institutions will then be combined to form the country's third largest bank. Scotiabank expects to hold an approximate 80 per cent stake in the new bank with Banca Intesa retaining approximately 20 per cent. Banca Intesa will pay about $266 million US for its stake. 
"We have been part of the Peruvian market for eight years and we see great potential in this market," said Rick Waugh, Scotiabank's president and CEO. "This agreement demonstrates our commitment to grow the bank through strategic acquisitions in key markets in Latin America." 
Scotiabank operates in Mexico, El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Costa Rica, Panama and Chile. The bank also has affiliates in Peru and Venezuela and a representative office in Brazil. 
Shares of Scotiabank gained 62 cents to close at $46.15 on the TSX.

title: Barrick gets apology in libel case over market manipulation allegations
content:
Barrick Gold Corp. said Friday it has won an apology and an undisclosed payment in a libel case over accusations from a U.S. company that Barrick conspired to manipulate the gold market. 
"We regret having made the statements that gave rise to the libel action filed by Barrick in Canada and any embarrassment those statements may have caused Barrick or its officers or directors," New Orleans-based Blanchard & Co. said in a press release issued by Barrick (TSX:ABX). 
On Dec. 18, 2002, Blanchard, the largest retail dealer of gold coins and bullion in the United States, filed an anti-trust lawsuit against Barrick and investment bank J.P. Morgan Chase accusing the companies of conspiring to illegally manipulate the gold market. 


Blanchard's suit alleged that Barrick and J.P. Morgan injected millions of additional ounces of gold into the market so that the companies made $2-billion US in short-selling profits "by suppressing the price of gold at the expense of individual investors." 
On March 5, 2003, Barrick filed a libel notice against Blanchard. Barrick said at the time that Blanchard had made comments that were "totally irresponsible and defamatory." 


Barrick shares dipped 10 cents, closing at $31.70 on the TSX.

title: Loblaw profits fall on supply-chain problems
content:
Loblaw Co. Ltd. said Thursday that problems with its supply chain pulled its earnings almost 26 per cent lower in the third quarter. 
The Toronto-based grocery chain (TSX:L) saw its profit fall to $192 million (70 cents a share) from $258 million (94 cents a share) a year ago. 
Loblaw said 9 cents of the per-share drop was related to restructuring charges and the costs associated with disruptions in its supply chain. The company had earlier warned that restructuring would eat into its earnings. 
Sales for the third quarter increased to $8.7 billion from the $8.1 billion reported in the third quarter of 2004. Same-store sales growth was flat during the quarter due to the supply chain disruptions, with the general merchandise, and health and beauty care departments experiencing the greatest impact, the company said. 
Loblaw's president John Lederer told analysts that the revamp of the company's supply network had taken longer and been more disruptive than planned. 
Loblaw shares were down $1.90 to $66.10 on the TSX. 
Loblaw's chain includes the Loblaws, Provigo, Zehrs and No Frills banners.

title: Fairfax Financial boosts stake in Torstar
content:
Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. has paid nearly $11.8 million to increase its holding of Torstar Corp.'s non-voting shares to 40.6 per cent.
The Toronto-based financial company now owns about 28.9 million class B shares of Torstar, owner of the Toronto Star, the Metroland group of newspapers and other digital and print media businesses.
Fairfax says it paid $1.25 each for the 9.4 million class B shares. The shares closed Thursday at $1.30 on the Toronto Stock Exchange, but Fairfax didn't say when its shares were acquired through a private agreement.
Fairfax says it acquired the class B shares for investment purposes but, in future, it may discuss transactions with management or the company's board of directors.
The company has gradually increased its stake over the recent years. Prior to the most recent transaction, it owned 27.3 per cent of the media company's non-voting shares.
Fairfax is a holding company that's primarily invested in insurance businesses. However, it has also made major investments in other Canadian companies including BlackBerry Ltd., International Forest Products, and Cara Operations.
In the wake of news of Fairfax's acquisition, Torstar shares rose 10 cents on Friday to close at $1.40 on the TSX.

title: Penn West posts record results
content:
Penn West Energy Trust rode high oil and gas prices to record financial results in the third quarter, the company said Wednesday. 
Penn West (TSX:PWT.un) said it made $210 million ($1.29 per unit), up 173 per cent from the same quarter a year earlier. Cash flow surged 41 per cent to $335 million ($2.06 per unit). 
Production in the quarter averaged 99,800 barrels of oil equivalent a day . 
When Penn West converted to an income trust earlier this year, it said it planned to distribute 60 per cent of its cash flow to unit-holders and hang on to the other 40 per cent to reinvest in development. 
But on Wednesday, it said if current oil and gas prices continue for the rest of the fiscal year, the current distribution level will amount to only 44 per cent of cash flow. It said it is currently using the excess cash flow to fund capital expenditures and reduce debt. 
Penn West paid out its first dividend on July 15 and recently announced a 19 per cent boost for the next cash payment set for Nov. 15. 
Penn West units were up $1.11 to $33.11 on the TSX.

title: PBB Global Logistics rejects takeover bid
content:
PBB Global Logistics Income Fund on Monday turned down a $180 million unsolicited takeover bid from Livingston International Income Fund. 
A customs broker and global shipping company based in Fort Erie, Ont., PBB (TSX:PBB.un) said Livingston's bid was too low, adding that it would also result in an 18 per cent drop in annual cash distribution to PBB unitholders and cause "adverse" tax consequences for investors. 


PBB said it also considering its strategic alternatives. Several parties have been granted confidential access to PBB's data, the company said. 
On Oct. 19, when Livingston unveiled its bid, it offered PBB unitholders 0.92 of a unit of Livingston in exchange for each PBB unit, which Livingston said represents a 17 per cent premium over the Oct. 18 closing price. 
Livingston International (TSX:LIV.un) is a Toronto-based customs broker. 
Units of PBB rose 30 cents to end at $17.60, while Livingston was up 29 cents at $20.09.

title: Vincor shareholders told to reject $1.4B takeover bid
content:
Management at Vincor International Inc. has formally turned down a $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid from U.S.-based Constellation Brands. 
Vincor (TSX:VN) , Canada's largest wine company, issued the rejection late Thursday, calling on shareholders to spurn the offer as too low. 
Constellation Brands launched its $31-a-share bid for Vincor on Sept. 27. The company formalized its takeover bid earlier this month when it mailed its offer to Vincor shareholders. 


"We believe that this offer significantly undervalues the business operations of Vincor," said Mark Hilson, chairman of Vincor's board. 
Constellation criticizes Vincor's board 
Constellation Brands was quick to criticize the Vincor board's recommendation to reject its offer. 
"Vincor's Board remains entrenched in the position it took even before we announced our $31 per share cash offer," said Constellation's chairman Richard Sands. 
"Its reasons were flawed then and are flawed now, yet Vincor's Board continues to reject the only existing value-enhancing alternative for its shareholders," he said. 
Earlier on Thursday, Vincor reported a second-quarter profit of $14 million (42 cents a share) on revenue of $182.6 million. In the same quarter a year ago, the company made $10.9 million (32 cents a share) on revenue of $165.7 million. 
Constellation's wine brands include Woodbridge by Robert Mondavi, Inglenook, Paul Masson, Hardys, and Banrock Station. Its best known liquor brand is Black Velvet. 
Mississauga, Ont.-based Vincor's brands include Inniskillin and Jackson-Triggs.

title: Printing operations weigh on Quebecor earnings
content:
Quebecor Inc. said weaker results at its printing subsidiary, Quebecor World, pulled its overall net income down in the third quarter. 
Quebecor (TSX:QBR.sv.b) said it made $22.6 million (35 cents a share), down from $41 million (63 cents a share) a year earlier. 
The company said its operating income dropped by $40.1 million year-over-year to $381.4 million in the third quarter. 
Quebecor Media saw its operating income increase by $5.7 million, while Quebecor World's operating income fell by $44.9 million. 
The company's total revenues came in at $2.52 billion, a decrease of $108.6 million year-over-year. 
"Quebecor's revenues and operating income continued to be impacted by the effect of challenging conditions in global print media markets on Quebecor World's operating results and by the impact of the conversion of Quebecor World's results into Canadian dollars," said company president and CEO Pierre Karl Peladeau, in a release. 
Quebecor also blamed its lower net income on a $60 million loss on the settlement of debt at Quebecor Media. 
Shares of Quebecor were off 8 cents at $25.15 on the TSX.

title: TransCanada earnings rise on sale of subsidiary
content:
Natural gas pipeline operator and power producer TransCanada Corp. reported higher third-quarter income thanks to the sale of a subsidiary. 
The Calgary company (TSX:TRP) said it made $427 million (88 cents a share), but that included an after-tax gain of $193 million (40 cents a share) from the sale of TransCanada Power LP to Epcor. For the third quarter of last year, the company made $245 million (51 cents a share). 
Factoring out one-time gains, TransCanada made $234 million (48 cents a share) in Q3 of this year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had a consensus forecast of 50 cents a share. 
The company said that during the third quarter, Bruce Power L.P. closed an agreement with Ontario Power Authority to restart and refurbish Bruce A nuclear power units on October 31. TransCanada increased its ownership interest in Bruce Power A units and will invest in the $4.25 billion restart and refurbishment program. TransCanada's approximate $2.13 billion share will be financed through contributions from 2005 to 2011. 
TransCanada operates a network of 41,000 kilometres of pipeline that ship most of Western Canada's natural gas to markets in Canada and the United States. The company also has interest in power generators in Canada and the U.S. 
Shares of TransCanada were up 22 cents at $35.29 on the TSX.

title: Takeover of PetroKazakhstan approved by Alberta court
content:
PetroKazakhstan's $4.2-billion US takeover by China National Petroleum Corp. has won court approval in Alberta, the company said early Wednesday. 
Calgary-based PetroKazakhstan (TSX:PKZ) said it was pleased with the decision of Justice Neil Wittmann of the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench. 
PetroKazakhstan said it plans to close the takeover deal as soon as possible after the judge's order has been filed in court. 
After PetroKazakhstan shareholders endorsed the takeover, China National Petroleum's cash offer of $55 US per share for the company hit a delay last week. 
That's when Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil, asked the Alberta court to hold up the sale while it sought a ruling on whether it should have the first opportunity to buy an oil field it and PetroKazakstan co-own. 
Lukoil took its quest for PetroKazakhstan a step further on Tuesday when it pledged to match China National's bid if the Alberta court held up the takeover bid. 
PetroKazakhstan shares gained 36 cents to end at $64.35 on the TSX.

title: Nortel sells HQ building to Rogers Communications
content:
Rogers Communications is shelling out $100 million to buy Nortel Network's massive corporate headquarters building in Brampton, Ont., the companies announced Tuesday. 
Rogers (TSX:RCI.nvb) gets the one-million-square-foot office space along with 57 hectares of land. The company is scheduled to take possession of the site on Jan. 4, 2006. 
Nortel (TSX:NT) said it is planning to relocate to two offices in the Toronto area, a sales studio and a larger corporate centre. 
"Nortel will continue to have a significant presence in the Toronto area in order to remain close to customers, be in close proximity of the financial capital of the country and to leverage the large talent pool in the area," Bill Owens, Nortel's chief executive officer said in a release. 
According to Nortel's website, the Brampton location houses the company's Canadian sales, marketing, global operations, human resources, finance and legal departments, among others. 
Rogers Communications currently has its corporate offices in several buildings in downtown Toronto.

title: Constellation begins hostile takeover bid for Vincor
content:
Constellation Brands has formally begun its $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid for Canada's biggest winemaker, Vincor International. 
The U.S. liquor company filed its takeover proposal with regulators and said it would send Vincor shareholders details of its offer later this week. 
Constellation (NYSE:STZ) is offering $31 a share in cash for each Vincor (TSX:VN) share. 
The offer "provides substantial value to Vincor shareholders at a level well beyond what we believe Vincor could achieve on its own in the increasingly competitive global wine industry," Constellation chief executive Richard Sands said in a statement Tuesday. 
But Vincor's board again rejected the offer as inadequate, saying it "does not represent fair and full value for our company." 
A Vincor statement repeated its position that "Constellation had earlier verbally presented a price indication of $36 or higher." 
Vincor shareholders seem to think a higher bid is in the offing, either from Constellation or another suitor. Vincor shares are trading above $34 on the TSX â more than $3 above Constellation's takeover offer. 
Constellation's wine brands include Woodbridge by Robert Mondavi, Inglenook, Paul Masson, Hardys, and Banrock Station. Its best known liquor brand is Black Velvet. 
Vincor's brands include Inniskillin and Jackson-Triggs.

title: Ballard Power CEO leaves company
content:
The president and chief executive officer of Ballard Power Systems Inc. has left the company. Ballard said late Wednesday the departure of Dennis Campbell was mutually agreed upon and effective immediately. 
The fuel cell maker said the departure of Campbell follows the recent sale of Ballard's German subsidiary, Ballard Power Systems AG, and Ballard's recently completed restructuring. 
"I'm extremely proud of the accomplishments that the Ballard organization has delivered under my watch," Campbell said in a release. 
"'We are a stronger, more focused company, with a clear vision and a plan to change the world for the better," he said. 
John Sheridan, the chairman of the board and a retired president and chief operating officer of Bell Canada, has been named interim replacement for Campbell. 
Vancouver-based Ballard (TSX:BLD) said it was also launching a hunt for a permanent president and CEO. 
In September, Ballard announced plans to cut 100 jobs in a move to save about 12 per cent on its annual operating expenses. 
Shares of Ballard closed down 18 cents at $5.84 on the TSX.

title: Zenon warns of Q3 operating loss
content:
Zenon Environmental warned Wednesday that production delays will result in the company posting an operating loss in the third quarter. 
Before the markets opened Wednesday, Zenon (TSX:ZEN) announced that its Q3 results would be below expectations because of difficulties in shifting production to a new type of water treatment technology. 
The company said it anticipated a quarterly operating loss of $4 million to $6 million. 
Zenon makes membrane products that municpalities and industries use to purify water. 
"Due to production process issues, the company did not achieve projected production levels on the new product," a company statement said. 
"However, most of the major manufacturing challenges have now been overcome with some minor issues yet to be resolved." 
Zenon shares lost $1.28 to end at $23.37 on the TSX. The shares dipped as low as $21.05 in early trading before rebounding. 
Zenon said the delays will hurt both revenue and profits in the third quarter, but it forecast a profitable fourth quarter and said its order backlog continues to grow. 
Zenon reports its Q3 results on Nov. 8.

title: JPMorgan suspends share buyback
description: CEO Jamie Dimon says bank is bracing for higher capital requirements
content:
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon says the bank is suspending plans to buy back its own stock.
Dimon said Monday the bank will continue to pay a dividend despite the $2 billion US trading loss disclosed on May 10.
"It's an embarrassment, it's a black mark," Dimon said of the trading loss. He also said the bank's balance sheet was "barely nicked" by the loss.
Speaking at a conference Monday organized by Deutsche Bank, Dimon said JPMorgan, the biggest bank in the United States by assets, is preparing for new international regulations that force banks to hold more capital to prepare for economic downturns.
JPMorgan's was scheduled to buy back $15 billion shares through the end of the first quarter of 2013.
JPMorgan's stock closed down 2.9 per cent to $32.51 US in trading on Monday.
The company is under investigation by the FBI over the massive trading loss.

title: Stelco shares higher on 1st day of trading
description: Firm to use money for capital investments, pension payments, product offerings
content:
Stelco Holdings Inc. shares gained almost 13 per cent on its first day of trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Stelco priced its initial public offering at $17 a share to pull in an expected $200 million. Its stock finished up $2.20 at $19.20 on the TSX.
The Hamilton-based steel company says it plans to use the money for capital investments, pension payments, and to increase its offerings in specialized steel products.
It wants to grow its offerings in galvanized steel, in part to regain a foothold in the nearby auto industry where it used to have a significant presence.
The company says it could also invest in co-generation to reduce its reliance on Ontario's high electricity costs, and thereby reduce operating costs in the power-intensive industry.
Stelco's history goes back to 1910 but in recent years has been beset by financial problems. It went into creditor protection in 2004 and was sold as a subsidiary to U.S. Steel Co. in 2007, then went back into creditor protection in 2014 before being sold to Bedrock Industries L.P. in late 2016.
At the end of June, Stelco emerged from creditor protection under its original name, having eliminated $3 billion of debt and about $1.4 billion of pension and other retirement obligations.

title: FPI earnings fall, company suspends quarterly dividend
content:
FPI Ltd. reported a sharp drop in its second-quarter net income to $1.1 million and said Friday it is suspending its quarterly dividend. 
The seafood company (TSX:FPI) said it made 7 cents a share in the quarter. During the same period last year, FPI made $4.1 million, or 27 cents a share. 
The St. John's company said its sales were $203.6 million, an increase of $11.1 million from $192.5 million in the same quarter of the prior year. 
The company said the increase in sales was mainly attributable to strong sales volumes at Ocean Cuisine International during the quarter. 
FPI's businesses include Ocean Cuisine, a Massachusetts-based division that serves foodservice, retail, and industrial customers throughout North America. FPI's other unit, called the primary group, harvests, processes and sells seafood products. 
"The primary group continues to feel the impacts of currency exchange rates, rising fuel prices and intense competition from low cost producing countries like China," said Derrick Rowe, the CEO of FPI. 
"The delayed opening of the Newfoundland and Labrador crab fishery this year also had a negative effect on the primary group's results for the quarter," Rowe said. 
FPI also said Friday it has suspended its quarterly dividend. The company said the dividends will be reviewed again by its board following the results of the third quarter and the anticipated conversion of Ocean Cuisine International into an income trust. 
FPI shares were down 5 cents at $7.20 on the TSX.

title: Finning International sees Q2 profit leap 64%
content:
Heavy equipment distributor Finning International Inc. reported record second-quarter earnings Tuesday of $45.6 million, a jump of 64 per cent over the same period a year ago. 
The results translated into earnings of 51 cents per diluted share, compared with $27.8 million or 35 cents per diluted share for the period ended June 30 last year. 
Revenue was $1.27 billion, up $239 million or 23 per cent from the same quarter in 2004. 
Vancouver-based Finning, which is one of the world's largest Caterpillar equipment dealers, said the results reflect continued strength in equipment spending by resource-based businesses in both Canada and South America. 
"Our second-quarter results are extremely positive and continue on the strong performance we experienced in the first quarter of this year," CEO Doug Whitehead said in a release. 
"Business conditions remain buoyant and our strong order book points to a solid second half of 2005 and a good start for 2006," he said. 
While pleased with the results of the Canadian and South American operations, Whitehead expressed disappointment with Finning's United Kingdom division, where gross profit was lower in both absolute dollars and as a percentage of revenue. 
Whitehead said Finning and Caterpillar have completed a joint review of the business model for the UK dealership and changes will start to be made later this year that are expected to lead to "meaningfully improved results in due course." 
Shares of Finning International (TSX:FTT) were up 27 cents to $37.87 on the TSX.

title: Fairweather buying Les Ailes de la Mode stores
content:
Fairweather Group will buy four Les Ailes department stores for $6.2 million from Groupe Les Ailes de la Mode Inc., the companies said Tuesday. 
The Quebec company (TSX:MOD) put the four stores â a Montreal flagship location and Quebec outlets in Brossard, Laval and Sainte-Foy â up for sale last month. 
"On its own, the Les Ailes department stores would have required significant capital investments to remain viable in the long term," said David Margolis, who announced his resignation as CEO and president of Groupe Les Ailes. 
"As part of the Fairweather Group, it will now benefit from the scale, purchasing power and relationships as well as the synergies that a large retailer can bring," he said. 
Margolis's interim replacement as CEO of Groupe Les Ailes will be Leslie Glazerman, who will also keep his current job of interim chief financial officer. 
Isaac Benitah, the president and CEO of Fairweather, said the Les Ailes' $75 million in revenues and 630 employees give it "a solid foundation from which we can build by leveraging the significant assets and resources of the group and further improve the profitability of the stores." 
Groupe Les Ailes de la Mode still operates a swimwear division with 59 swimwear boutiques in Quebec and Ontario under the Bikini Village and Ocean Bikini Village banners. 
Shares of Les Ailes were unchanged at 33 cents on the TSX. 
Headquartered in Toronto, Fairweather has stores in every Canadian province except Prince Edward Island.

title: Aeroplan Income Trust units priced at $10
content:
A price of $10 per unit has been set for the 25 million units of the Aeroplan rewards program being converted into an income trust by Air Canada's parent company, ACE Aviation Holdings. 
ACE said the final prospectus for the Aeroplan Income Fund will be filed with securities regulators on Wednesday. 
The underwriters also have an option to purchase up to 3.75 million additional units at the offering price within 30 days of closing. 
This is in line with expectations that ACE would try to raise $287.5 million, consisting of $250 million in the initial public offering and another $37.5 million through the so-called over-allotment option. 


"The Aeroplan IPO is a significant step in ACE's commitment to further illuminate the value inherent in it business units," Milton said. "This is a solid endorsement by the market of ACE's business strategy going forward." 
The income fund will own 12.5 per cent of Aeroplan, rising to 14.4 per cent if the over-allotment option is fully exercised. 
The fund will retain about $100 million of the IPO's net proceeds to help fund a reserve for Aeroplan mile redemptions and for capital expenditures. The remaining $125 million will go to ACE for general corporate purposes. 
Aeroplan has also arranged with Royal Bank of Canada, whose investment arm is the lead underwriter for the IPO, for a $450 million secured credit facility, of which $300 million will be used to fund the balance of the reserve for Aeroplan mile redemptions. 
ACE (TSX:ACE.RV)said the units are expected to provide a cash-on-cash yield of seven per cent annually based on the initial offering price, with the first distribution to be paid by Aug. 15. 
The fund is expected to begin trading on the TSX about June 29 under the symbol AER.UN. 
Shares of ACE were unchanged at $41.50 on the TSX.

title: Alcan stock jumps on bottle business announcement
content:
Alcan is contemplating the sale of its plastic bottle business, the company said Friday. 
The announcement drove Alcan stock up almost three per cent in TSX trading. Alcan closed up $1.10 to $38. 
The plastic bottle unit had 2004 sales of $130 million US and 495 employees at three plants in the U.S., one in Canada and one in France. 
The aluminum company has been tightening its focus recently, and said the announcement was part of that process. 


Alcan wants to move further into the flexible packaging market, "where we already enjoy substantial scale and leadership positions and where we believe the most attractive growth opportunities lie," Christel Bories, president and CEO of Alcan Packaging, said in a statement. 
The bottle business supplies juice, fast food and drink sellers, and all kinds of grocery manufacturers, who make products like pasta sauce, jams and condiments. 
Alcan (TSX:AL) hired J.P. Morgan Securities to look at the options for the business. 
Alcann shares have traded between $36.10 and $62.80 in the past year.

title: Goodfellow Inc. mulls converting to income trust
content:
Shares of Quebec hardwood flooring company Goodfellow Inc. shot up by more than 22 per cent Thursday after the board of directors announced it will study whether to convert the firm into an income trust. 
The board said it concluded at its latest meeting a week ago that in light of recent steps by other companies in the industry, and as the fiduciary for the shareholders, that it should study the advantages and disadvantages of conversion. 
"Any decision to be taken will be taken after such a study, in which the interests of all shareholders, employees, clients and the long-term future of the company will be paramount," the board said in a release. 
It emphasized that "no decision has been taken at this moment and that it is entirely possible that the company may decide not to proceed with this step." 
Goodfellow (TSX:GDL)is Eastern Canada's largest independent re-manufacturer and distributor of lumber products and the largest distributor of hardwood flooring in Canada. 
Goodfellow shares, which were halted pending the morning announcement, closed up $5.75 to $31.00 on the TSX.

title: Mega Bloks buying crafts and toy firm Rose Art for $350M US
content:
Shares of Mega Bloks Inc. jumped more than 11 per cent after the firm said it will pay $350 million US to buy the privately held arts, crafts and toy company Rose Art of New Jersey. 
Mega Blok shares were up $2.20 at $20.75 on the TSX. 
Montreal-based Mega Bloks (TSX:MB) said Rose Art is the No. 2 brand in the $1.8 billion US arts and crafts category. Rose Art's product line also features school supplies, plus games and puzzles. 
The deal will see Mega Bloks assume $35 million US in outstanding debt. The deal is for cash plus the issuance of $20 million US in Mega Bloks common stock. 
Rose Art recorded sales of $285 million US, and income from operations of $43 US million for the year that ended March 31, 2005. 
For the same 12-month period, Mega Bloks had revenue of $237.7 million US and income from operations of $31.9 million US. 
Mega Bloks CEO Marc Bertrand said the acquisition will boost his company's earnings per share by over 15 per cent on a full-year basis. 
"We see a tremendous opportunity to accelerate international sales of Rose Art's products through Mega Bloks' well-established global sales and distribution network," said Rose Art CEO Lawrence Rosen. 
Mega Bloks said the combined company would have pro forma sales of $523 million US and income from operations of $75 million US for the 12 months ended March 31.

title: Goldman Sachs to pay $7M US settlement
content:
U.S. bank Goldman Sachs will pay $7 million US to settle federal regulators' civil charges that its futures brokerage business failed to diligently supervise activity in trading accounts from mid-2007 through 2009.   
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission says it reached the settlement with the big Wall Street bank, which agreed to pay a $5.5 million civil fine and $1.5 million in restitution. Goldman also said it has made changes in its supervision policies, procedures and training to prevent a recurrence.   
The division, Goldman Sachs Execution & Clearing, failed to investigate signs of questionable conduct by an unnamed brokerage firm that was one of its clients, the CFTC said.
Goldman received about $1.5 million in fees and commissions for transactions it made for the brokerage firm, according to the agency.

title: Novelis revises profit downward by $30M US
content:
An accounting change forced aluminum rolled-products company Novelis Inc. to slash $30 million US off its first-quarter profit Thursday, just one day after it reported lower earnings. 
Novelis, which was spun off by Alcan Inc. in January, said quarterly profit actually dropped to $29 million US from $69 million for the same period a year ago. 
On Wednesday, it had reported net earnings of $59 million or 78 cents a share. The revised earnings amount to 39 cents a share, down from 92 cents a year ago. 
The change arose from the accounting treatment of losses incurred between Jan. 1 and Jan. 6, around the time of the company's effective spinoff from Alcan, CEO Brian Sturgell told analysts in a conference call Thursday. 
The issue revolved around how Novelis had accounted for fluctuations in the price of aluminum and swings in the value of its aluminum hedge contracts. 
Chief financial officer Geoffrey Batt apologized for the revision and said the company would take steps to prevent it from happening again. He noted the change had no impact on the company's previously announced cash flow or balance sheet. 
Shares of Novelis (TSX:NVL) closed down 13 cents at $27.77 on the TSX.

title: GM to sell natural gas-powered trucks
content:
The world’s largest automaker announced plans Monday to sell pickup trucks that can run on both gasoline and compressed natural gas.
General Motors will launch two pickups in April that can "seamlessly" transition between the two fuels.
The vehicles will be sold in both Canada and the United States
According to a statement, GM says drivers could save between $6,000 to $10,000 in fuel costs over three years. That’s because natural gas is about one-third the cost of gasoline.
The Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra 2500 HD pickups will have tanks for both fuels. GM expects the range of the vehicles to be over 1,000 kilometers.
GM began selling cargo vans that run on compressed natural gas in 2012.

title: Valeant shares rise after $930M sale of iNova business
description: Company to pay down debt with proceeds
content:
Shares of Valeant Pharmaceuticals Inc. rose almost five per cent on Friday after the company announced it has completed the sale of its iNova Pharmaceuticals business for $930 million in cash.
The Quebec-based company says it will use net proceeds of about $920 million from the sale to reduce its debt.
CEO Joseph Papa said the sale of iNova to Pacific Equity Partners and the Carlyle Group is also part of Valeant's efforts to simplify its portfolio and focus on its core businesses.
The company's stock rose 79 cents to close at $17.88 on the TSX on Friday.
Valeant shares have plunged since questions about its business model first emerged two years ago, when they traded for more than $300 per share.
The company has since faced a string of lawsuits, including one from its former chief executive, as well as swelling debt levels, losses of more than US$2.4 billion and scrutiny over its drug pricing practices.
Following the anticipated closure of the sale of its Obagi Medical Products business this year, Valeant says it expects it will exceed its August 2016 commitment to pay down $5 billion in debt before February 2018.

title: Rothmans' Q3 earnings down but splits stock, boosts dividend
content:
Rothmans Inc. shares traded higher on Friday as the company beat third-quarter expectations, boosted its cash dividend and announced a stock dividend. 
The tobacco company said it made $25.4 million (75 cents a share), down from $25.9 million (77 cents a share) a year earlier. 
Despite the profit decline, Rothmans (TSX:ROC)earnings were still ahead of the analysts' consensus forecast of 77 cents offered by Thomson One Analytics. 
Shares of the Toronto-based firm gained almost seven per cent, or $2.94 a share, to hit $45.45 on the TSX. 
Sales at its 60 per cent-owned subsidiary Rothmans, Benson & Hedges Inc. (RBH) were $164.1 million for the quarter after factoring out excise duty and taxes, compared with $170.0 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2004. 
"While external factors that we cannot control will continue to affect buying patterns and create volatility in the marketplace, we are confident that our earnings for fiscal 2005 will be stronger than those seen in fiscal 2004," said John Bennett, the company's president and CEO. 
The company boosted its quarterly dividend by 10 cents to 60 cents a share, and announced a two-for-one stock split in the form of a stock dividend. 
"This increased distribution to our shareholders reflects our confidence in the underlying strength of performance at our subsidiary, RBH," said Barnett. 
"The stock dividend will effectively achieve a two-for-one split, making Rothmans Inc.'s shares more affordable and accessible to a wider range of investors," he added.

title: Cedara Software being acquired in $476.6M stock deal
content:
Cedara Software Corp. of Toronto is being acquired by Merge EFilm of Milwaukee in an all-stock deal worth about $476.6 million, the companies announced Tuesday. 
Merge EFilm, a global health-care software and services company, said it will issue either 0.587 of one of its common shares, or 0.587 shares of a newly created class of Canadian exchangeable shares, for each common share of Cedara, an independent developer of medical software technology. 
The deal is valued at about $15.10 for each common share of Cedara. The companies said the offer includes 17.5 per cent premium to Cedara's 20-day volume weighted average stock price. 
Cedara shares closed Monday up seven cents at $13.92 on the TSX. But the takeover deal barely moved Cedara stock. It was off 2 cents to $13.90 in trading on the TSX on Tuesday. 
Merge EFilm shares were off 6 cents US, closing at $19.49 US on Nasdaq. 
The deal is expected to close in April. 
The corporate headquarters for the combined company will be in Milwaukee, Wisc. Richard Linden, Merge EFilm's president and CEO, will hold those positions in the new company, while Cedara president and CEO Abe Schwartz will serve as a member of its board of directors.

title: Pizza Delight parent company shrinking Moncton corporate office
description: Number of staff affected unclear
content:
The company that operates Pizza Delight throughout Atlantic Canada as well as other restaurant brands in several provinces says it will shrink its Moncton corporate office and relocate the finance function to its headquarters in Montreal.

Pizza Delight has most of its 90 locations in Atlantic Canada and a support team will continue to be located in Moncton.

In addition to Pizza Delight, Imvescor Restaurant Group (TSX:IRG) owns the Mikes, Scores and Baton Rouge brands.

The company said Tuesday it would reduce corporate staff levels by 10 per cent but didn't indicate how many people or jobs would be affected.

It announced that Tania Melanie Clarke has been appointed as its new chief financial officer, one of several recent changes to the management team.

Imvescor says the corporate finance department will be moved from Moncton to the Montreal HQ before the end of November.
