title: Mega Bloks wins SCOC ruling on Lego trademark
content:
Canada's highest court ruled unanimously Thursday that Mega Bloks does indeed have business in the playrooms of the nation, along with Lego. 
The Supreme Court of Canada decision marks the end of a long-running trademark battle between the Montreal-based Mega Bloks and Denmark's Lego. 
The ruling means that Montreal-based Mega Bloks (TSX:MB) can continue to sell its products in Canada. 
Lego Canada and Lego holding company Kirkbi AG first took Mega Bloks to court in 1996 over the bumps on the blocks, alleging Mega Blok's products were infringing on Lego's trademark. 
Lego sought an injunction and damages from Mega Bloks. Lego believed it had a trademark on the look of the knobs on its blocks. 
After losing in lower courts, Lego appealed the case to the country's top court. Lego argued that Mega Bloks' advertising of its blocks could cause confusion between the two companies' products. 
'The monopoly on the bricks is over': Supreme Court 
On Thursday, the Supreme Court justices concurred with a lower court judge who found that "purely functional" features, such as the well-known geometrical pattern of raised studs on the top of the bricks, could not be the basis of a trademark. 
"Trademark law should not be used to perpetuate monopoly rights enjoyed under now-expired patents," the Supreme Court says. 
The last of Lego's Canadian patents on its blocks expired in 1988. 
"The fact is ... that the monopoly on the bricks is over, and Mega Bloks and Lego bricks may be interchangeable in the bins of the playrooms of the nation â dragons, castles and knights may be designed with them, without any distinction," the high court ruled. 
Mega Bloks sells its products in more than 100 countries. Sales in the most recent quarter were $163.5 million. It made a profit of $20.4 million. 
Shares of Mega Bloks finished up 49 cents, closing at $25.16 on the TSX.

title: EnCana's Morgan to step down at end of 2005
content:
Gwyn Morgan, the man who built EnCana Corp. into the biggest independent oil and gas producer in North America, will step down at the end of the year and be replaced by the company's current chief operating officer, Randall Eresman. 
The energy giant (TSX:ECA) said Morgan will remain on as executive vice-chairman for the year 2006, working mainly in an advisory capacity to Eresman. 
Gwyn joined EnCana predecessor Alberta Energy Company Ltd. in October 1975. He was responsible for drilling the wells that resulted in AEC's first production and was head of the oil and gas division. 
In early 2002 he led the merger of two of Canada's largest oil and gas firms to create EnCana Corp., which is currently North America's largest producer of natural gas. 
Eresman, a petroleum engineering graduate from the University of Wyoming, joined Alberta Energy Company in 1980. He was appointed chief operating officer of EnCana soon after its creation. 
"I have seen Randy develop over a quarter century and for the past decade he has been a key part of my executive team. Randy's ethical foundation, business judgment and exceptional industry knowledge give me great confidence in the future of EnCana under his leadership," Morgan said in a release. 
EnCana denied rumours last week that Royal Dutch Shell might be kicking the tires before taking a run at acquiring the company. Morgan reiterated that to CBC Business News host Fred Langan Tuesday. 
"We have never, ever had any discussions with Shell," he said. 
EnCana shares rose $1.29 to close at $61 on the TSX.

author: Pete Evans
title: Aeroplan strikes deal with Amazon for shoppers to earn points online
description: Loyalty card members must access Amazon through the Aeroplan website
content:
Owners of the Aeroplan loyalty program have struck a deal with online retailing giant Amazon that will enable the loyalty program's five million members in Canada earn reward points while shopping online.
Starting in April, Aeroplan members who visit Amazon.ca through Aeroplan's web portal will be able to earn Aeroplan miles for every dollar spent.
The deal is contingent on accessing Amazon through Aeroplan's website, as opposed to just shopping directly at Amazon.ca. But Aeroplan members with silver and black status can earn more than one mile per dollar, just as they normally would, as long as they shop via the portal.
"With an ever-increasing amount of shopping being done online, we're thrilled that our members will now be able to earn Aeroplan Miles on Amazon.ca, allowing them to get closer to their travel plans," said Vince Timpano, president of coalitions at Aimia Inc., the TSX-listed company that owns Aeroplan.
"Our members have big travel plans, so making every single purchase work hard for them — even as they change where they shop — is critical to our continued evolution as the trusted companion for savvy travelling Canadians."
It's the service's biggest partnership since it announced last May that Air Canada had decided to sever ties with the company, starting in 2020.
Aimia shares, which had been trading at around $9 each before the Air Canada news, plunged and have since been changing hands at about $1.60 a share, more than 80 per cent lower. The shares took a new tumble as recent as last week when Aimia announced that members would no longer be able to earn miles at Esso gas stations starting June 1, with the gas chain moving its loyalty program to PC Optimum instead.
But investors responded positively to Monday's news, as Aimia shares rose almost 20 per cent to $1.90 in afternoon trading on Monday.

author: Pete Evans
title: Top Canadian CEOs paid almost 159 times the average worker's salary last year
description: CEOs of 60 biggest public companies in Canada earned an average of $7.89 million in 2015
content:
The CEOs of Canada's biggest companies are paid 159 times more than average workers, according to a report from consultancy Gallagher McDowall & Associates.
The consultancy has tracked executive compensation for the past six years, dating back to 2010. In this year's report, released Friday, they looked at executive compensation among the members of the TSX 60, which is a list of the 60 most valuable publicly traded companies in Canada. The group also delved into compensation practices at the next 60 largest firms, for a total pool of 120 Canadian companies.
Among the top tier, the numbers suggest that executive compensation actually declined in 2015 from the previous year's level. All in, the typical CEO of a TSX 60 member company took in $7.89 million last year, down from $7.99 million in 2014.
The tier below, however, saw their pay packets increase from $3.91 million in 2014 to $4.06 million last year.
That's not just cash  — it includes base salaries, bonuses, stocks, stock options, pensions and other forms of compensation.
While compensation for the top tier appears to have stabilized, it's done so after having risen by about 25 per cent in the previous six years, the report says. Managing director Robert Levasseur says in an interview that there's a clearer trend toward higher compensation at larger companies versus smaller ones.
"The larger the company, the higher the pay," he says. 
Exorbitant pay packages have come under increased scrutiny in recent years, but lost in the shuffle, Levasseur says, is the notion that high-income CEOs also contribute a disproportionately large amount to Canada's tax base.
According to the report, the average CEO of one of Canada's biggest 60 companies paid $3.47 million in taxes last year, roughly 44 per cent of their income. That compares with the average industrial worker, who the report says paid $8,067 in income taxes, or 16 per cent of their pay packet.
The company estimates that Canada's top CEOs paid about $200 million in income tax last year, a figure which is roughly equivalent to what 25,000 average industrial workers would have collectively paid.
That calculation does not factor in any tax avoidance strategies that may have been used, and instead is culled from a model that calculates what a person would pay in taxable income on investment gains were their stock-based compensation to be booked as regular income.
"There's this assumption that when you're a very high earner you don't pay any tax," Levasseur says. "These people earn a lot of money but by the same token they do pay a substantial amount of tax."
All in all, Levasseur says, executive compensation at large Canadian companies still pales in comparison to what happens at U.S. ones, where the CEO-to-worker compensation ratio currently sits at more than 300 to  one.
Levasseur says he's reluctant to come up, when asked, with a number of what the ratio should be as an ideal.
"It's really hard to determine what's reasonable," he says. "I don't know if Jose Bautista's or Sidney Crosby's compensation is reasonable, but they operate in an open market — they are getting out of the system as much as they can."
More important than how much a CEO is paid or how much they are paid compared to their workers is whether or not the company is getting value for that money.
"It's incumbent on boards to ensure they are comfortable with compensation," he says, "but they have to be paying these people based on performance."

title: Sleeman Breweries cutting jobs as revenue, earnings fall
content:
Sleeman Breweries reported lower sales and earnings in the second quarter, and said it's eliminating 40 jobs. 
The Guelph, Ont., beer company (TSX:ALE) said it made $2.5 million (15 cents a share), down from $3.8 million (23 cents a share) in the second quarter of 2004. 
The company's revenue for the quarter was $57.9 million compared to $58.7 million a year earlier. 
"We had a challenging quarter due to the wet and cool spring across the country, the National Hockey League lockout and continued price discounting in our key markets," said John Sleeman, the company's chairman and CEO. 
"In addition, the second quarter of last year benefited from the distribution strike in British Columbia and the first summer sales of our very successful low carbohydrate beer Sleeman Clear," he said. 
The company said the 40 job cuts come as it tries to reduce its costs by $1 million in the current fiscal year. Sleeman will record a one-time charge of $2.1 million in the third quarter in connection with the job cuts. 
"After several years of expansion, it is time to take a closer look at the way we operate and make the necessary changes to improve the business and our cost structure for the future," said John Sleeman. 
"These initiatives will help us achieve our target of 10 per cent annual normalized [earnings per share] growth in the current fiscal year and will leave us well positioned for the future." 
Sleeman shares fell 50 cents on Wednesday to close at $13.50 on the TSX.

title: ACE Aviation Holdings turns Q2 profit, announces plans for Jazz spinoff
content:
ACE Aviation Holdings, the parent company of Air Canada, posted a second quarter profit of $168 million, a rebound from the $510-million loss posted a year earlier due to massive restructuring charges. 
The company (TSX:ACE.rv) also revealed plans to spin off a minority portion of its Jazz regional carrier via an income trust. ACE said it plans to file preliminary prospectus in the third quarter. In June, ACE spun off just over 14 per cent of its Aeroplan frequent flyer loyalty program. 
The company's earnings per share was $1.49, against a loss of $4.24 a year ago. 
ACE's operating income for the quarter was $177 million, an increase from the operating income before reorganization and restructuring items of $22 million recorded in the second quarter of 2004. 
The company's operating revenue for the quarter was $2.46 billion, up from $2.22 billion a year earlier. 
"Our revenue performance, in terms of both traffic and yield, was strong and gained momentum throughout the quarter," said Robert Milton, the chairman, president and CEO of ACE. 
"Looking forward, the revenue picture is expected to continue to strengthen as we increase capacity in North America with new large regional aircraft deliveries," Milton said. 
ACE said that rising fuel costs will be a concern in the future. A $1 US per barrel increase in the price of West Texas Intermediate oil costs the company about $28 million in fuel expenses, the firm said. 
The company has been using surcharges to deal with its fuel costs, but now plans to implement "a systematic fuel risk management strategy using financial instruments to build up our hedge position." The company said it plans to hedge about half of its future fuel within two years. 
Shares of ACE gained $2.34 to close at $39.84 on the TSX.

title: Zimbabwe unveils $50-million bank note to cope with rampant inflation
content:
Authorities in Zimbabwe have issued a new mega bank note in an attempt to cope with the troubled African country's runaway inflation.
The size of the new note? Fifty million Zimbabwean dollars. 
The new bill, issued Friday, marks the third time in three months that the central bank in Harare has issued a higher denomination note in response to the country's 100,000 per cent annual inflation rate. 
In practical terms, the $50-million bill is worth just $1 US in trading on Zimbabwe's widely used black market. 
That means it can buy just three loaves of bread.

title: Talisman Energy Q2 profit jumps 76%
content:
Rising oil and gas prices and higher production pushed Talisman Energy Inc.'s second-quarter profit up by 76 per cent to $340 million, the company reported Thursday. 
The results translated into earnings of 93 cents a share, compared with $193 million or 50 cents a share for the same period a year ago. 
The Calgary-based oil and gas producer said gross sales for the quarter ended June 30 rose by 22 per cent to $2.1 billion. 
The company said the impact of a stronger Canadian dollar was more than offset by a combination of higher commodity prices, new production from Trinidad, increased oil and liquids production in Algeria and a boost in natural gas production in North America and Southeast Asia. 
Production averaged 444,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up two per cent from the same quarter in 2004. The figure was down slightly from the first quarter due to maintenance and plant turnarounds. 
"Talisman continues to deliver extremely good financial results on the back of steady year over year volume growth, with production per share up seven per cent year to date," CEO Jim Buckee said in a release. 
"Drilling results in North America continue to be very good with a number of promising wells about to test," he said. 
"Tweedsmuir, our major field development in the North Sea, is on schedule for first production early in 2007," Buckee said. "The South Angsi Field in Malaysia will commence production within the next few weeks. We also expect to spud our first onshore well in Trinidad during the third quarter." 
The company said it expects the South Angsi startup and higher natural gas volumes, along with fewer plant turnarounds, to push third-quarter production to between 450,000 and 470,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. It estimates it will add a further 30,000 barrels in the fourth quarter. 
Shares of Talisman (TSX:TLM)gained $1.36 to $54.06 on the TSX.

title: Adanac Molybdenum secures $80M in interim financing
content:
Shares in Adanac Molybdenum Corp. (TSX:AUA) rose almost 56 per cent Wednesday after the metals miner announced it has secured an offer for $80 million in bridge financing.
Adanac said it has signed a term sheet with an unidentified "leading global institutional investor" for financing to fund continued development of its proposed Ruby Creek molybdenum project in northern British Columbia.
"This financing would advance our Ruby Creek project to the next level," chief executive David Stone said in a statement.
"The funding would enable Adanac to continue its engineering and construction planning activities and take possession of processing equipment we have ordered for the molybdenum mine."
The proposed issue of senior secured notes is expected to be completed in mid-May, pending regulatory approval, due diligence by the investor and a definitive agreement.
Adanac embarked on a $750-million debt and equity financing initiative for the mine last October and expects to complete its financing this summer.
Adanac stock, which was halted pending announcement of the financing, gained 33 cents to close at 92 cents Wednesday, in heavy trading of 2.9 million shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
On Thursday, that price fell 9 cents to 83 cents.
The company's shares have traded in a 52-week range between 51 cents and $2.67.

title: Owners angling to sell GSW
content:
Two companies that control GSW Inc., a Canadian consumer products manufacturer, are in talks with a U.S. competitor to sell the whole company, GSW said Friday. 
GSW did not identify the companies, but according to a recent securities filing, Valleydene Corp. controls GSW through its holding of A stock and owns almost 36 per cent of the B subordinate voting shares, while Gardiner Group Capital owns more than 40 per cent of the B shares. 
Valleydene is owned by John Barford, chairman of GSW, and Elizabeth Malcolm, a GSW director. 
The company said the shareholders are talking to A. O. Smith of Milwaukee, Wisc., "regarding a possible sale transaction. The majority shareholders have confirmed to GSW that the transaction currently under discussion would be made available to all shareholders of GSW on the same terms." 
GSW is providing A.O.Smith with confidential information, it said. 
GSW subordinate voting Class B stock (TSX:GSW.sv.b) , which is thinly traded, closed up $23.25 or almost 40 per cent at $82.25, even though the company warned that talks could take months and might fail. Volume was just 9,400 shares. 
The company makes water heaters, niche building products and applicances, through its 20 per cent stake Camco (TSX:COC) . Camco closed down 15 cents at $2.10. 
GSW profit was $4.5 million ($1.31 a share) for the three months ended March 3, compared with $2.4 million (69 cents) a year earlier. 
Sales were $144.9 million, compared with $133.3 million. 
GSW dates back to 1847, when it made stoves as McCleary Manufacturing Co. GSW stands for General Steel Wares. 
It has 600 Canadian and 1,000 U.S. employees.

title: Inex Pharmaceuticals slashes more staff as CEO departs
content:
Inex Pharmaceuticals Corp. says its chief executive officer David Main and two other executives are departing as the company continues to slash its workforce in a bid to conserve cash and chart "a new strategic path." 
The Vancouver-based firm announced Tuesday that Timothy Ruane has been appointed president and CEO, effective immediately. Ruane had been senior vice-president of corporate development. 
Inex said it is cutting its workforce by more than half to 22 employees from 57, which will reduce its expenditures to less than $1 million a month. 
This is the company's second round of deep staff cuts. In December, it announced it was eliminating 103 of its 165 personnel. 


The company said the latest reductions will result in severance costs of about $4.4 million, leaving it with working capital of $16 million going into the third quarter beginning July 1. 
Main had been with Inex since 1996 and became president in July 1999. Also leaving are Tom MacRury, senior vice-president of technical operations, and Alexandra Mancini, senior vice-president of clinical and regulatory affairs. 
"David's outstanding leadership was critical in the company's transformation from a research-driven to a product-focused biopharmaceutical company, and Tom and Alex both made important contributions to the company over many years," Darrell Elliott, chair of the company, said in a release. 
"We are also grateful for the dedication of our other departing employees," he said. 
Inex (TSX:IEX)said its lead cancer drug, Marqibo, has shown "promising" results in clinical trials, but it won't complete protocols for the Phase 3 trials with the FDA until it secures a new partner for the drug. 
Shares of Inex closed down three cents at 36 cents on the TSX. They had traded as high as $6.28 last year.

title: Cineplex Galaxy buying Famous Players for $500M
content:
Two major Canadian movie theatre chains are uniting as Cineplex Galaxy LP said Monday it will buy Famous Players from Viacom Inc. for $500 million. 
Famous Players operates 81 theatres across the country with 787 screens. The chain runs the Coliseum, Colossus, Paramount and SilverCity brands. 
Based in Toronto, Cineplex operates or has interests in 86 theatres with 775 screens in six provinces under the Cineplex Odeon and Galaxy brands. 
Under an agreement with the federal Commissioner of Competition, Cineplex Galaxy will have to sell off 35 theatres with annual box office revenues of $100 million to complete the deal. 
Cineplex has agreed to sell theatres in Victoria, Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton, Lethbridge, Saskatoon, Winnipeg, London, St. Catharines, Kitchener, Hamilton, Kingston, Ottawa, Toronto, Gatineau, Montreal and Quebec City. 
"Given the degree of concentration in the industry and the barriers to entry into the market, it is essential that these theatres be sold off to ensure that this merger does not result in a substantial prevention or lessening of competition," said Gaston Jorre, the senior deputy commissioner of competition. 
Cineplex's takeover of Famous Players is expected to close during the third quarter. 
Cineplex, which is majority owned by Onex Corp., said it will finance its takeover of Famous Players with debt and equity. 
"Working in conjunction with Onex Corporation, our largest unit-holder and controlling partner, we are bringing together two great companies and are creating an exceptional opportunity to build value through an improved cost structure and expanded product offerings," said Ellis Jacob, the president and CEO of Cineplex. 
Last year, Famous Players had revenue of $520 million while Cineplex had revenue of $354 million. 
Cineplex Galaxy Income Fund (TSX:CGX.un) owns 42 per cent of Cineplex Galaxy LP. Units of the fund gained 44 cents to close at $14.64 on the TSX. Shares of Onex Corp. slipped 10 cents to end at $19.05.

title: Cerberus ponders takeover bid for Royal Group Technologies
content:
News that Cerberus Capital Management LLP is considering a $1.08-billion takeover bid for Royal Group Technologies sent shares of Royal up by more than 12 per cent on Monday. 
Royal Group shares gained $1.52 at close at $13.70 on the TSX. 
Prior to the opening of stock markets, Royal Group said Cerberus had "stated its desire to conduct 'due diligence investigations' in connection with a potential offer for shares of the company." 
Royal Group (TSX:RYG.sv) said if Cerberus is satisfied with its research, it then will make a $14-per-share offer. 
Cerberus later confirmed its interest in Royal Group and the terms under which it may buy the company. 
Cerberus has already struck deals with company founder Vic De Zen, Domenic D'Amico and others to buy up to 18.6 million shares, representing approximately 19.9% of the outstanding equity of the company. 
Royal Group, a plastic building products company entangled in police and regulatory investigations, last week posted a first-quarter loss of $11.4 million or 12 cents a share. 


Royal is based in Woodbridge, Ont., north of Toronto. Founder Vic De Zen was ousted in November along with the company's president and chief financial officer after forensic accountants uncovered a land deal in Woodbridge involving a private company in which De Zen had a stake. 
Other controversies involve Royal's dealings with a Caribbean resort project controlled by De Zen and allegations of price fixing in the U.S. market.

title: Oilsands plant fire hits Suncor bottom line
content:
A January fire at a Suncor oilsands facility in northern Alberta caused first-quarter profits to drop more than half, the company said Thursday. 
Suncor (TSX:SU) said it made $98 million (22 cents a share) in the quarter, compared to to $216 million (48 cents a share) it made in the same quarter a year earlier. 


The Jan. 4 fire at Suncor's facilities led to a big drop in production in the first three months of the year. Production averaged 175,600 barrels of oil equivalent a day in Q1, down more than 30 per cent from its average in Q1 of 2004. 
Cash flow in the quarter also dropped 30 per cent to $294 million. 
"We're disappointed with the quarter, but not surprised," Suncor chief executive Rick George said in a statement. "We know that from a financial perspective, the first nine months of the year will not deliver to our normal expectations. However, we're focused on safely returning production to full capacity and recovery is going very well," he said. 
The facilities will be repaired and back in production by September, the company said, forecasting that production capacity would be 350,000 barrels a day by 2008. 
Suncor filed an application last month to build a third oilsands upgrader. The upgrader plant is estimated to cost $5.9 billion. Later this year and next year, Suncor will submit separate applications for plans to provide bitumen feed to the proposed upgrader. That could cost another $4 billion. 
The expansion in Fort McMurray's oilsands is part of a new oil boom, spurred by higher prices for crude oil that makes producing and refining heavy oil economical. 
Suncor shares were down 7 cents to $45.83 at the close on the TSX.

title: Easyhome offers to settle class-action suit for $7.38M
content:
Easyhome Ltd., which operates 143 appliance and furniture rental stores across Canada, said Friday it has reached a tentative settlement in a class-action lawsuit by 70,000 customers over claims of excessive interest rates. 
Easyhome has agreed to pay $7.38 million in coupons which can be used to buy merchandise or apply against new or existing rental agreements. The settlement is subject to court approval. 
The company will also be required to pay the plaintiffs' legal fees, which have yet to be set by the court. 
The lawsuit, launched in April 2004, originally sought $200 million in damages. 
The plaintiffs alleged that the company used rental agreements for furniture and other items to charge fees and expenses that constituted interest rates in excess of 60 per cent a year, the maximum permitted interest rate in the Criminal Code of Canada. 
The fees were charged either at the contract's expiration or pursuant to an early pay-out option. 
Easyhome has also undertaken to revise its rental agreements so the difference between pay-out amounts and the cash price of merchandise cannot be construed as an interest charge in excess of the rate prescribed by law. 
However, the company insists that since it doesn't advance credit, the agreements don't involve any interest charges whatsoever. "The settlement does not constitute any admission of liability," the company said in a release. 
"Nonetheless, it made good business sense to avoid the expense, time and distraction that this lawsuit created," CEO David Ingram said. 
Easyhome (TSX:EH)describes itself as Canada's largest rental-purchase company and the fourth largest in North America. It rents furniture, appliances and home electronics. 
Shares of Easyhome dropped $1 to $23 in light trading of 7,750 shares on the TSX.

title: CAE cutting 450 jobs, reduces dividend amid Q3 loss
content:
Flight simulator company CAE Inc. announced plans to cut 450 jobs and slash its dividend as it reported a $347 million third-quarter loss. 
The Montreal company (TSX:CAE) said its quarterly results were hit by a $443.3 million special charge to reduce the value of goodwill, intangible and tangible assets. 
The loss totalled $1.40 a share, compared with a profit of $21.4 million, or 5 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. 
CAE's revenue rose to $257.2 million from $255.2 million. 
The company said it will wind up saving about $20 million a year by cutting its annual dividend to 4 cents a share from the previous 12 cents a share. 
As part of a corporate reorganization, CAE will create a simulation products division, leading to the consolidation of all its manufacturing activities, include engineering, program management and global procurement. CAE said those functions had previously been duplicated in its civil training and military divisions. The reorganization is effective April 1. 
"Our plan will change the way we do business," said Robert Brown, CAE's president and CEO. 
"This has been a challenging time, requiring difficult decisions," said Brown. "To eliminate duplication and to achieve a more competitive cost structure, we will be reducing our head count by some 450 people." 
The cuts amount to about eight per cent of CAE's 5,500 employees. About 350 of the cuts will be in Montreal. 
During the fourth quarter, CAE will record a $30-million charge for workforce reduction and related expenses. An additional restructuring cost in the range of $25 to $35 million will be incurred over the course of fiscal year 2006. 
Brown pointed to three reasons for the sweeping changes at the company: the prolonged difficulties in the airline industry; the rise of the Canadian dollar; and the company's inability to produce a simulator at the cost the market wants. 
Investors responded to the flurry of developments by sending CAE shares down by 17 cents to $5.20 on the TSX.

title: Sears Canada buying Cantrex Group
content:
Sears Canada Inc. has agreed to purchase Cantrex Group in a move it says could generate up to $120 million more in annual revenue. 
Cantrex is a buying group that deals with 400 suppliers to provide merchandise for some 1,300 retail outlets across Canada, under banners such as Furniture Plus, Mattress World and carpet sellers End of the Roll. 
Sears Canada (TSX:SCC) said Thursday it has agreed to buy the company from a Canadian subsidiary of General Electric Capital Corp. The transaction includes Cantrex subsidiary Corbeil Electrique Inc., a Montreal-based appliances retailer operating mainly in Quebec. 
Financial terms of the deal, which is expected to close in April, were not disclosed. 
Sears Canada CEO Brent Hollister called it a "strategic acquisition" that further develops the company's merchandising and buying power in the furniture and appliance sectors. 
The company has estimated the deal could generate annual revenue of between $100 million and $120 million, according to spokesman Vincent Power. The money would come from merchandising services, such as fees to Sears Canada for helping secure, warehouse and ship products, as well as revenue from the six corporate-owned Corbeil outlets. 
Further revenue could flow from its financial services business if the retailers that Cantrex serves allow the Sears Card to be used by consumers in their stores. 
John Chamberlain, an analyst with Dominion Bond Rating Service, said the deal could provide a boost to Sears Card business, especially since the cards would be used to buy more big-ticket items that are often paid off over time, generating more interest revenue. 
"We have no plans to do that right away," Power said. "If the independent retailers who are part of the Cantrex group would like that Sears Card service and we're able to make that happen, then you could potentially see the Sears Card used in those stores by their customers." 
Shares of Sears Canada closed up 24 cents at $16.83 on the TSX.

title: Viking Energy to buy Calpine Natural Gas Trust
content:
Viking Energy Royalty Trust agreed to buy Calpine Natural Gas Trust, in a stock swap deal valued at about $380 million. 
The boards of directors of the two Alberta-based companies on Wednesday announced terms of an agreement whereby Viking would pay two of its shares (TSX:VKR.UN)for every CNG Trust unit ( TSX:CXT.UN). 


Viking would issue two of its units for each of Calpine Natural's approximately 27.1 million units, valuing the deal at $379.4 million. 
"This transaction represents an important step in the strategy of Viking," said Viking CEO John Zahary. "The combination of CNG Trust's high-quality natural gas assets with our strong base of oil production will create a fund with excellent stability for future distributions." 
Viking is acquiring Calpine at a small discount to its market value, based on Tuesday's prices. Calpine units closed at $14.30, while Viking units closed at $7, on Tuesday. 
Viking units ended down 7 cents $6.93, and Calpine Natural units finished down 55 cents to $13.75, in trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange. 
The combined entity, of which Calpine unit trust holders would own about 33 per cent, would have a market capitalization of $1.15 billion, the companies said. Their combined current production was about 23,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
"CNG Trust unit holders should anticipate receiving a 6.7 per cent increase in distributions per unit, from 15 cents to 16 cents, based on recent historical monthly distributions of Viking and the proposed two-for one exchange ratio," they added. 
The combined trust would have significant operations in central and southern Alberta, operating more than 80 per cent of its total production â about half of which is natural gas.

title: Judge OK's currency change fee lawsuit against BMO
content:
A class-action lawsuit against BMO Nesbitt Burns, BMO Investorline and BMO Trust Company (TSX:BMO) has been certified by the Ontario Superior Court.
The suit accuses BMO of automatically converting any foreign currency that was paid into RRSP accounts into Canadian dollars without authorization.
It further alleges that BMO charged undisclosed or inadequately disclosed and unauthorized fees related to the foreign currency transactions.
None of the allegations have been proven in court.
BMO said it was disappointed with the decision and that it would defend the case, but declined further comment because it was before the courts.
The Income Tax Act allowed foreign currency to be held in a registered account after June 14, 2001.

title: Adanac Molybdenum secures $80M in interim financing
content:
Shares in Adanac Molybdenum Corp. (TSX:AUA) rose almost 56 per cent Wednesday after the metals miner announced it has secured an offer for $80 million in bridge financing.
Adanac said it has signed a term sheet with an unidentified "leading global institutional investor" for financing to fund continued development of its proposed Ruby Creek molybdenum project in northern British Columbia.
"This financing would advance our Ruby Creek project to the next level," chief executive David Stone said in a statement.
"The funding would enable Adanac to continue its engineering and construction planning activities and take possession of processing equipment we have ordered for the molybdenum mine."
The proposed issue of senior secured notes is expected to be completed in mid-May, pending regulatory approval, due diligence by the investor and a definitive agreement.
Adanac embarked on a $750-million debt and equity financing initiative for the mine last October and expects to complete its financing this summer.
Adanac stock, which was halted pending announcement of the financing, gained 33 cents to close at 92 cents Wednesday, in heavy trading of 2.9 million shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
On Thursday, that price fell 9 cents to 83 cents.
The company's shares have traded in a 52-week range between 51 cents and $2.67.

title: Province halts private prosecution against Mount Polley tailings spill
description: Bev Sellars had filed court documents alleging that Mount Polley Mining Corp. polluted the environment
content: The B.C. Prosecution Service announced Tuesday it will not pursue private charges in the 2014 collapse of the tailings dam at the Mount Polley mine. The charges were filed by Indigenous woman Bev Sellars days after British Columbia's government announced that provincial charges would not be laid. On August 4, 2017, Bev Sellars swore a private Information alleging that the Mount Polley Mining Corporation (MPMC) had committed various offences contrary to the provincial Environmental Management Act and Mines Act. The prosecution service says it does not usually permit a private prosecution to proceed. In this situation however it reviewed everything Sellars submitted. "After conducting its review, the BCPS concluded that the material provided does not meet the charge assessment standard for approval of charges," it said. Citizens can pursue private prosecution if they believe an offence has been committed, but in B.C., the Crown can decide not to proceed if it believes there is no reasonable prospect of conviction. Sellars was the acting chief of the Xat'sull First Nation, located near the gold and copper mine in B.C.'s Cariboo region, when the dam collapsed on Aug. 4, 2014. Proud to support @BevSellars as she seeks justice after the #MtPolley disaster, three years ago today: https://t.co/SoH8wtnZ7P #bcpoli pic.twitter.com/uxhXpVdLBa An investigation into the dam's collapse is ongoing by the B.C.'s Conservation Officer Service. Officials have said that the service is working with the federal government concerning possible violations of the Fisheries Act. There is a five-year deadline for charges to be laid. Two reports, by B.C.'s chief inspector of mines and an independent panel of engineering experts, found the collapse involving the mine operated by Imperial Metals Corp. (TSX:III) was caused by a poorly designed dam that didn't account for drainage and erosion failures. The Mount Polley mine went back to full operations in 2016. With files from the Canadian Press.

author: Pete Evans
title: Brexit fallout continues as pound hit new lows
description: British pound has lost almost 20 cents US since voters chose to leave EU last week
content:
The British pound hit fresh new lows on Monday as investors who drove the currency to its lowest level since 1985 last week found new reasons to worry about the prospect of Brexit.
Sterling dropped 4.22 cents US to reach 132.13 cents. That's lower than the 31-year low of 132.40 cents that sterling hit on Friday, when the result of Britain's Brexit vote showed a majority Britons want to leave the European Union.
At one point before the vote, the British pound was trading at $1.50.
"Sterling is vulnerable to further near-term selling pressure," said Athanasios Vamvakidis, FX strategist at Bank of America Merril Lynch. "A push below $1.30 cannot be ruled out," he added.
The TSX lost ground again, falling 202.09 to close at 13,689.79. Metals, energy and bank stocks led the way down.
Monday's march lower comes on the heels of a 239-point drop on Friday.
Bank stocks again came under pressure on Monday.
"A lot of the expectations about what these financial stocks would be worth have changed," said JJ Kinahan, chief strategist at TD Ameritrade.
The Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays both had their shares halted after declining by as much as 15 per cent.
Oil was also punished, losing $1.31 to settle at $46.33 a barrel. The loonie followed suit and moved lower by 0.44 of a cent to close at 76.49 cents.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 260.51 points to 17,140.24, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 36.87 points to 2,000.54.

Standard & Poor's said Monday it has stripped the U.K. of its top credit grade in the wake of the vote to leave the E.U. The rating agency downgraded the country's sovereign rating by two notches, from AAA to AA, saying the vote is a "seminal event" that "will lead to a less predictable, stable and effective policy framework in the U.K."
It is also keeping a negative outlook on the rating, which means it could downgrade the country further.
It added in a report that the outlook reflects the risk to the economy and public finances, as well as the pound's role as an international reserve currency.
Fitch also cut its credit rating on the U.K., dropping it one notch to AA from AA+.
George Osborne, chancellor of the exchequer — Britain's equivalent of the finance minister — worked to assuage investors that the ruling Convervatives have a plan to deal with Brexit's financial impact.
"It will not be plain sailing in the days ahead," Osborne said. "But let me be clear. You should not underestimate our resolve. We were prepared for the unexpected."
His words alone were not enough, however, as the pound lost another three per cent on Monday.
"Markets will be nervous given that the EU and U.K. have some mismatch in terms of timing of exit procedures and negotiations," Mizuho Bank analysts said in a report.
Osborne pledged not to impose a new austerity budget, even though he said during the campaign that one would be necessary if voters chose to leave the EU.
He also said the job of formally declaring Article 50 — the EU rule that must be invoked for any member nation to leave the bloc — would fall to whoever replaces Prime Minister David Cameron, who said Friday he would be stepping down.

title: CoolBrands files $360M suit against Weight Watchers
content:
The legal fight between CoolBrands International Inc. (TSX:COB.a)and Weight Watchers International Inc. entered another round on Wednesday after CoolBrands filed a lawsuit seeking $360 million in damages over allegations of breach of a licensing agreement. 
CoolBrands contends that it has the exclusive rights to use the Weight Watchers trademark to make and sell ice cream and frozen novelty products until Sept. 28, 2004. CoolBrands also says it has the non-exclusive rights to keep using the Weight Watchers trademark for another year after that day. 
However, CoolBrands alleges that Weight Watchers signed a licensing deal with Wells' Dairy late in July 2004. CoolBrands said that deal violates its existing agreement. 
Weight Watchers countered that it properly entered into its deal with Wells' Dairy. 
"Weight Watchers strongly believes that this counter suit filed by CoolBrands is completely without merit and Weight Watchers will vigorously contest the matter," the company said in a release. 
None of the allegations have been proven in court. 
Shares of CoolBrands fell 16 cents to $10.10 on the TSX on the day. 
In late July, CoolBrands' shares took a hit after the company said that it had failed to sign an extension of the licensing agreement with Weight Watchers International.

title: Coolbrands buys U.S. ice cream distributor from Parmalat
content:
Coolbrands International Inc. (TSX:COB.a)said Monday it has purchased the Kinnet Dairy DSD ice cream distribution business from financially troubled Parmalat. 
Kinnet Dairy's business is located primarily in Georgia, with additional distribution coverage in parts of Alabama and South Carolina. 
Financial terms of the sale were not disclosed. 
"This acquisition expands our distribution footprint, adds operational synergies and enhances our strategic value as a favoured vendor to retailers in the grocery and convenience channels across the Southeast region," said David Stein, CoolBrands' president and co-chief executive officer. 
"Acquiring smaller regional systems such as Kinnet Dairy is part of our strategy of expanding and strengthening our [distribution] system," said Stein. 
Coolbrands said that in July 2003 it acquired virtually all of Nestle's distribution assets in the U.S., giving it a network of operations in Washington, Oregon, California, Utah, Florida, Georgia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and the District of Columbia. 
 Separately, Parmalat Dairy & Bakery Inc. said it has lined up $610 million in refinancing of its Canadian operations with the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan. 
The money will go to paying down debt and the company's general operations, Parmalat said. 
"This financing will allow Parmalat Dairy & Bakery Inc. to refinance all of its existing senior debt and provide it with the financial resources necessary to execute its business plans," Nash Lakha, the company's executive vice president and CFO, said. 
Parmalat Dairy & Bakery's Canadian brands include Astro, Beatrice, Black Diamond and Lactantia. 
The dairy and bakery's parent company, Italy's Parmalat Finanziaria SPA, declared insolvency in 2003 after accounting irregularities were disclosed. 
Shares of Coolbrands were up 5 cents to $21.55 on the TSX.

title: Inter Pipeline buys natural gas plants for $715 million
content:
Inter Pipeline Fund (TSX:IPL.un)says it has a deal to buy stakes in three natural gas liquids (NGL) extraction plants from Williams Energy (Canada) Inc. for $715 million. 
If deal closes, Inter Pipeline said it will increase its cash payout to 75 cents per unit a year, up from the current 72 cents. 
The fund said it raised the money for the acquisition by borrowing and issuing new units worth $250 million. 
The three plants, two in Empress, Alta. and one near Calgary, had average sales of $623 million and average operating profit before taxes, interest, and depreciation of $81 million in the three years from 2001 to 2003, the fund said. 
In 2003, the plants produced about 137,000 barrels a day of NGL, including ethane and a mixture of propane, butane and pentanes-plus. 
Ethane is a feedstock for petrochemicals, and is made into products such as polyethylene, rubber, plastics, solvents and foam materials. 
The propane, butane and pentanes-plus mix becomes fuel and fuel blends. 
The plants have long-term sales contracts with an average life of 13 years, Inter Pipeline said. 
The assets it bought include 100 per cent of the Empress II and Cochrane plants, and 50 per cent of Empress V. 
Units of Inter Pipeline were off 20 cents at $7.64 on the TSX. 
Together, the plants "represent one of the largest NGL extraction businesses in North America," the fund said. 
Williams Energy (Canada) is a subsidiary of Williams Cos. Inc. (NYSE:WMB)of Tulsa. It said it expected to make a $190 million US pre-tax profit on the sale.

title: Forzani pays $1.7M settlement
content:
Sporting goods retailer Forzani (TSX:FGL)has agreed to pay $1.7 million to settle concerns about advertising at its Sport Chek and Sport Mart stores. 
The company has not admitted anything, but under a consent agreement registered with the federal Competition Bureau on Tuesday, Calgary-based Forzani will pay an administrative penalty of $1.2 million plus $500,000 in costs for the investigation. 
However, the regulator and the company disagree about what Forzani is alleged to have done. 
The bureau said the company "has agreed to stop misleading consumers" with ads that inflated the regular prices of certain products, making the savings from sale prices seem greater than they actually were. 
The bureau also disagreed with the use of "original price" in advertising, comparing the sale price with the original price. Forzani ran a disclaimer explaining that "original price" and regular price were not the same, but the regulator "took exception to the effectiveness of the disclaimer," the company said. 
Forzani said it hasn't been charged with anything and it doesn't admit to misleading consumers, as the bureau wrongly said. 
Forzani "has instructed its counsel to consider all appropriate legal remedies available to it in these circumstances," the company said in a statement. 
It said it settled the case on the advice of lawyers to avoid the expense of protracted litigation. 
The bureau said Forzani will publish corrective notices in newspapers across Canada, in Sport Chek and Sport Mart advertising flyers, in stores and on corporate websites. 
The bureau also said the company must stop references to "inflated regular prices" in advertisements and establish a program to ensure conformity with the deceptive marketing practices provisions of the Competition Act. 
Forzani operates 217 corporate stores under the banners of Sport Chek, Sport Mart and Coast Mountain Sports and 174 franchise stores under the banners of Sports Experts, Intersport, RnR, Atmosphere, Econosports and Tech Shop. 
Forzani shares closed down 42 cents at $13.38 on the TSX on Tuesday.

title: Gold soars, markets slump on growth worries
description: TSX has 6th straight loss
content:
Gold reached a new high Tuesday and North American stock markets sold off amid fresh worries about U.S. economic weakness.
Gold for December delivery rose as high as $1,647.80 US an ounce,  and closed at $1,644.50, up $22.80, or 1.4 per cent.
Shares of Canadian gold miners surged accordingly, with the S&P/TSX Global Gold Index rising 2.9 per cent.
But the broader benchmark S&P/TSX composite index finished down 193.31 points, or 1.49 per cent, to 12,752.32 — its sixth straight losing session.
In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 265.87 points, or 2.19 per cent, to 11,866.62. The Nasdaq composite index fell 75.37 points, or 2.75 per cent, to 2,669.24, while the S&P 500 index was down 32.89 points, or 2.56 per cent, at 1,254.05.
The Dow has fallen for eight consecutive sessions and the S&P for seven. The S&P 500 index is now at its lowest point of the year.
Gold prices have risen 15 per cent in 2011 and have gained for 11 straight years.
Investors have sought the metal as a safe haven amid concerns about slowing growth in the U.S. and China and whether a slowdown in Europe will result in the spread of that region's debt crisis from Greece, Ireland and Portugal to Spain and Italy.
The Canadian dollar declined 0.52 of a cent, to 104.14 cents US.
September oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed down $1.10, to $93.79 US a barrel.
Worries about U.S. growth were compounded Tuesday by evidence that consumer spending fell in June and on Monday by data from the Institute for Supply Management. The ISM's index of activity in the manufacturing sector fell to 50.9 during July from 55.3 the previous month.
That raised concerns that the economic weakness seen in the first half of the year was not just temporary.
"It might be a bit bigger than a soft patch," said Chris Kuflik, wealth adviser at ScotiaMcLeod in Montreal.
"The talk around the world has been centred around debt crisis. And what it's done is [lead] to some paralysis as far as people who are willing and able to invest money in businesses. They're hunkering down because of all the uncertainty."
Both sets of data are particularly bad news coming before the release Friday of the U.S. non-farm payrolls report. Job creation hopes for July were already muted.
A report on Sunday, meanwhile, said manufacturing in China, the fastest-growing economy in the world and best hope for global recovery, slowed.
HSBC's purchasing managers' index for China fell to its lowest level in 16 months.

author: Linda Nguyen
title: Travellers wait for relaunch of low-cost NewLeaf flight reseller
content:
As summer travel season gets underway, Canadians no doubt will be scanning the skies for bargain-priced flights. 
Some may have been expecting to fly with NewLeaf Travel, a Winnipeg-based startup that billed itself as an alternative to airlines like WestJet (TSX:WJA) and Air Canada (TSX:AC) when it launched in January to much public fanfare.
But a week after the company started selling tickets, it hit some turbulence over whether it needed a licence to operate.
NewLeaf suspended ticket sales and refunded flights it had scheduled for February as it awaited a ruling from the Canadian Transportation Agency.
The company contended that it did not require a licence because it is not an airline and doesn't operate airplanes. Instead, it purchases seats from Kelowna, B.C.-based Flair Airlines and resells them to the public. Flair Airlines, which owns and operates a fleet of Boeing 737-400 jets, is licensed under the CTA.
On March 30, the agency ruled in favour of NewLeaf and cleared the way for the company to resume ticket sales. At that time, NewLeaf CEO Jim Young said the company expected flights to take off in late spring or early summer.
Since then, there's been little movement from the company.
NewLeaf was planning to fly from:
Lisa Krishka, a spokeswoman for NewLeaf, said it still plans to begin travel this summer. She would not offer a specific restart date.
Canadian aviation experts say a number of reasons may be behind the lack of clarity on a relaunch.
On Thursday, the Federal Court of Appeal agreed to hear an appeal by air passenger rights advocate regarding whether the CTA has the authority to permit NewLeaf to operate without a licence.
At issue, according to Gabor Lukacs, is that other companies have operated under similar business models and have required licences.
He doesn't expect the court to hear the appeal until at least the fall, but urged that passengers need to be cautious while the case is still under review.
The court did not say whether NewLeaf would have to put off its relaunch until the hearing. The company did not respond to a request for comment late Thursday after the court's decision.
But Robert Kokonis, president at aerospace consultancy AirTrav Inc., suspects NewLeaf may be trying to beef up investment before they launch again.
"The airline business is a cash-intensive business," he said. 
Kokonis said there is demand for discount carriers in Canada where base fares are low but any add-ons, from luggage to seat selection, are considered extras and come with accompanying fees.
"(Canada) is the only major aviation market in the world that doesn't have an ultra-low cost carrier," he said, noting that a number of factors stay in the way.
"We have a very high cost structure, fees, charges, and taxes that scares away ultra-low cost carriers. The successful ultra-low cost carriers of the world in the U.S., in continental Europe and Asia, thrive on a very dense geographic area to offer flights. ... Canada is very dispersed with not a huge population."
Bruce Cran of the Consumers' Association of Canada said people should be wary when booking with new startups that operate under a new business models because they can be exempt from having to provide protections on baggage and cancelled flights afforded to passengers who directly book with established airlines.
"They should be cautious because this is something completely new that we've never had before in Canada," he said.

title: Nortel to announce unaudited Q1 and Q2 results by mid-August
content:
Nortel Networks (TSX:NT)said Tuesday it expects to be in a position to announce "limited preliminary unaudited results" for the first and second quarters of 2004 by mid-August. 
Nortel said work is continuing on the restatement of its financial results for 2001 through 2003. Based on the progress it's making, the company said it should be able to provide updated assessments of the expected impacts of the restatements by mid to late July. 
In April, Nortel fired CEO Frank Dunn and two other senior executives during a probe of accounting irregularities at the giant technology company. 


Nortel also announced Tuesday that it has reached an agreement to sell its factories in Canada and Brazil to Singapore-based Flextronics for about $700 million US. 
The company had been involved in talks with Flextronics since January. 


Flextronics is also expected to acquire the company's manufacturing operations in France and Northern Ireland. 
About 2,500 employees will be transferred to Flextronics. About 900 are in Montreal, 650 in Calgary, 100 in Ottawa and 30 in Brazil. In Europe, about 440 in Northern Ireland and 330 in France would transfer. 
Nortel shares closed up 34 cents at $6.68 on the TSX.

title: 'Blue Monday' the most depressing day of the year
content:
With the TSX plunging more than 500 points on Monday morning, more than a few Canadians might give credence to a British psychologist's pseudo-scientific formula that indicates Jan. 21 will be the most depressing day of 2008.
Cliff Arnall began calculating the happiest and gloomiest days of the year back in 2005 while working as a professor at Cardiff University in Wales.
At the behest of the British travel industry, Arnall devised a "Blue Monday" formula that calculates factors such as weather, debt, time passed since Christmas, failed New Year's resolutions, low motivation and the need to take action.
While there is no scientific support for Arnall's theory — some might find the formula 1/8W+(D-d)3/8xTQMxNA itself too depressing even to contemplate — anyone suffering from the winter blues or just a bad case of the Mondays can take comfort in the fact that they aren't alone.
Health Canada estimates two to three per cent of Canadians suffer from seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and another 15 per cent of Canadians suffer from a milder version simply known as the winter blues. 
These seasonal conditions can affect moods, sleep patterns, appetites, energy levels and concentration. Exercise, experts say, is the best way to keep seasonal depression at bay.

title: Appeal court reinstates McClean Lake mine's operating licence
content:
The Federal Court of Appeal has overturned a two-year-old ruling that quashed the operating licence for tailings management at the McClean Lake uranium mine and mill in northern Saskatchewan. 
Denison Mines Inc. (TSX:DEN)of Toronto has a 22.5 per cent stake in the facility, whose majority owner is French-based Cogema Resources Inc. 
A trial court ruled in September 2002 that the operating licence had been granted on the basis of an outdated environmental assessment. However, operations were allowed to continue while Cogema launched an appeal. 
The Court of Appeal unanimously agreed that the licence was properly obtained, despite changes in the law while the environmental review and licence process went on. 
Cogema's position was supported by the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission, the Saskatchewan government and the Lac La Ronge aboriginal band. 
The court awarded costs to Cogema, which a company spokesman described as "substantial." However, he said the company doesn't expect it will be able to collect the money from the Inter-Church Uranium Committee Educational Co-operative of Saskatoon, which originally took the case to court. 
"It's very disappointing from an environmental perspective," said a lawyer for the church group Stefania Fortugno, who added that an appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada is likely. 
"The court is ignoring the very serious implications of this mining project and the effects on future generations spanning the next 160,000 years," Fortugno said. 
The group had launched its case because of concerns that radioactive waste would seep into groundwater and lakes. 
Denison said Monday that the decision "will remove any uncertainty about the continued licensing of the McClean facilities and the licensing of several other projects that were licensed under the same circumstances as the McClean Lake operation." 
Shares of Denison closed down 8 cents to $6.14 in Monday trading on the TSX.

author: Pete Evans

Fitch also cut its credit rating on the U.K., dropping it one notch to AA from AA+.
George Osborne, chancellor of the exchequer — Britain's equivalent of the finance minister — worked to assuage investors that the ruling Convervatives have a plan to deal with Brexit's financial impact.
"It will not be plain sailing in the days ahead," Osborne said. "But let me be clear. You should not underestimate our resolve. We were prepared for the unexpected."
His words alone were not enough, however, as the pound lost another three per cent on Monday.
"Markets will be nervous given that the EU and U.K. have some mismatch in terms of timing of exit procedures and negotiations," Mizuho Bank analysts said in a report.
Osborne pledged not to impose a new austerity budget, even though he said during the campaign that one would be necessary if voters chose to leave the EU.
He also said the job of formally declaring Article 50 — the EU rule that must be invoked for any member nation to leave the bloc — would fall to whoever replaces Prime Minister David Cameron, who said Friday he would be stepping down.

title: Gold soars, markets slump on growth worries
description: TSX has 6th straight loss
content:
Gold reached a new high Tuesday and North American stock markets sold off amid fresh worries about U.S. economic weakness.
Gold for December delivery rose as high as $1,647.80 US an ounce,  and closed at $1,644.50, up $22.80, or 1.4 per cent.
Shares of Canadian gold miners surged accordingly, with the S&P/TSX Global Gold Index rising 2.9 per cent.
But the broader benchmark S&P/TSX composite index finished down 193.31 points, or 1.49 per cent, to 12,752.32 — its sixth straight losing session.
In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 265.87 points, or 2.19 per cent, to 11,866.62. The Nasdaq composite index fell 75.37 points, or 2.75 per cent, to 2,669.24, while the S&P 500 index was down 32.89 points, or 2.56 per cent, at 1,254.05.
The Dow has fallen for eight consecutive sessions and the S&P for seven. The S&P 500 index is now at its lowest point of the year.
Gold prices have risen 15 per cent in 2011 and have gained for 11 straight years.
Investors have sought the metal as a safe haven amid concerns about slowing growth in the U.S. and China and whether a slowdown in Europe will result in the spread of that region's debt crisis from Greece, Ireland and Portugal to Spain and Italy.
The Canadian dollar declined 0.52 of a cent, to 104.14 cents US.
September oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed down $1.10, to $93.79 US a barrel.
Worries about U.S. growth were compounded Tuesday by evidence that consumer spending fell in June and on Monday by data from the Institute for Supply Management. The ISM's index of activity in the manufacturing sector fell to 50.9 during July from 55.3 the previous month.
That raised concerns that the economic weakness seen in the first half of the year was not just temporary.
"It might be a bit bigger than a soft patch," said Chris Kuflik, wealth adviser at ScotiaMcLeod in Montreal.
"The talk around the world has been centred around debt crisis. And what it's done is [lead] to some paralysis as far as people who are willing and able to invest money in businesses. They're hunkering down because of all the uncertainty."
Both sets of data are particularly bad news coming before the release Friday of the U.S. non-farm payrolls report. Job creation hopes for July were already muted.
A report on Sunday, meanwhile, said manufacturing in China, the fastest-growing economy in the world and best hope for global recovery, slowed.
HSBC's purchasing managers' index for China fell to its lowest level in 16 months.

title: EnCana offers $2.7 billion US for Denver's Tom Brown
content:
EnCana Corp. (TSX:ECA)is expanding its natural gas holdings in the U.S. Rockies by offering $2.7 billion US for independent producer Tom Brown Inc. of Denver. 
Calgary-based EnCana said it will offer $48 US a share, a 24 per cent premium on Wednesday's closing price of Tom Brown common shares. The deal also includes the assumption of Tom Brown debt. 
"The U.S. Rockies have been EnCana's highest growth region and this acquisition is anticipated to take our U.S. gas production to 1 billion cubic feet per day," Gwyn Morgan, EnCana's president and CEO, said. 
"Tom Brown's assets are a hand-in-glove fit with our U.S. Rockies asset base," Morgan said. 
The acquisition of Tom Brown is expected to add about 325 million cubic feet equivalent per day of current gas production, about 1.2 trillion cubic feet of proved gas reserves and about 2 million net undeveloped acres to EnCana's operations. 
EnCana also announced plans to increase the size of its current divestiture program of conventional non-core properties in Western Canada. 
So far in 2004, the company has sold off about $380 million US of non-core assets, with the additional divestitures expected to bring in between $1 billion US and $1.5 billion US from the sale of conventional properties that currently produce between 40,000 and 60,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
Including the Tom Brown acquisition and the planned Canadian conventional divestitures, EnCana's 2004 U.S. production is expected to increase from 18 to 24 per cent of total production. 
Overall, North American production is expected to be 88 per cent of EnCana's total production, Randy Eresman, EnCana's chief operating officer, said. 
Shares of EnCana closed down 20 cents at $58.20 on the TSX. Tom Brown shares jumped $8.95 US to hit a new 52-week high of $47.72 US on the NYSE.

title: Reebok to buy CCM, Jofa, Koho brands in $329 million US takeover
content:
Shares of The Hockey Company Holdings Inc. (TSX:HCY)jumped more than 20 per cent on Thursday after athletic shoe and apparel maker Reebok International (NYSE:RBK)unveiled a takeover bid for the owner of some of the most famous hockey-gear brands in Canada â CCM, JOFA and Koho. 
Hockey Co. shares gained $3.88, closing at $21.08 on the TSX. Reebok shares were down a nickel at $42.04 US on the NYSE. 
Reebok's takeover offer is for $21.25 a share in cash. The overall deal is worth about $329 million US, including the assumption of $125 million US in Hockey Co. debt. 
"The Hockey Company's leading market position with elite athletes will enable Reebok to expand its reach to young athletes," Paul Fireman, the chairman and chief executive officer of Reebok, said. 
"Hockey is currently one of the world's fastest growing participatory sports, and there has been a dramatic increase in female participation," Fireman said. 
Hockey Co. has a long-term licensing agreement with the National Hockey League to supply jerseys to all 30 teams. The company also holds the exclusive global rights to make and market authentic and replica NHL jerseys. 
The company also has licensing deals with the Canadian Hockey League, the American Hockey League and the ECHL. 
Shareholders who own about 41 per cent of Hockey Co., including Wellspring Captial Management, have already agreed to Reebok's offer. 
Hockey Co. changed its name from SLM International in March 1999. 
Reebok's main competitor, Nike, moved into the hockey market in 1994 when it bought Bauer.

title: Aliant asks CRTC to ease rules on local phone service
content:
Aliant (TSX:AIT), the main telecom company in Atlantic Canada, on Wednesday asked regulators to ease the rules on service in highly-competitive residential areas â the first such request in the country. 
Aliant wants the Canada Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) to lift the restrictions on price, terms and conditions for local residential service in areas of Nova Scotia and Price Edward Island where competitors offer service. 
Aliant essentially wants to be able to offer special deals to its customers without prior public approval from the CRTC. 
Aliant faces local phone competition in Halifax and Charlottetown, mainly from Eastlink, a cable television company. 
"Current regulatory restrictions prevent us from offering what is considered by customers to be basic promotional offers," Heather Tulk, vice-president of broadband and marketing at Aliant, said. 
"We feel these restrictions do not provide our customers with the true benefits of competition, where customer needs set the direction for our company offers," Tulk said. 
Aliant also asked the CRTC for exemptions on some rules, including: 

Aliant also wants permission to file its promotional offers with the CRTC in private, so the company can launch them without competitors' knowledge. 
The request came one day after the CRTC sided with Eastlink by stating that Aliant cannot offer bundled packages that include Internet, wireless and local phone service without applying to the commission. 
Shares of Aliant were down 37 cents to $30.19 on the TSX.

title: Loonie, Canadian stocks sag as Brexit vote nears
content:
The loonie, a barrel of oil and Canadian stocks limped through a down day on Thursday ahead of the looming Brexit vote.
The price for benchmark U.S. crude oil for July sank $1.80 to close at $46.21 US a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange
The loonie, which is closely tied to the price of oil, dipped 0.21 of a cent to conclude at 77.15 cents US, its sixth straight losing session.  
On Bay Street, the S&P/TSX composite index fell 41.04 points to end at 13,882.41.
Meanwhile, U.S. stocks, which spent the morning in the red, ultimately finished with gains to end a five-session losing streak.
The  Dow Jones industrial rose 92.93 points to wrap up the day at 17,733.10. The broader S&P 500 added 6.49 points to finish at 2,077.99, while the Nasdaq composite ended at 4,844.92, up 9.99 points.

The market volatility comes as Britain prepares to vote on June 23 whether to remain in the European Union. Ahead of that vote, the Bank of England, which kept its rates on hold as well on Thursday, said a vote to leave would likely send the pound dropping sharply, and hurt spending and investment.
Meanwhile, the August gold contract gained $10.10 to settle at $1298.40 US. Although it topped $1,300 an ounce earlier in the session, the metal wasn't able to finish above that mark. Gold hasn't settled above $1,300 in more than a year.

author: Linda Nguyen
title: Travellers wait for relaunch of low-cost NewLeaf flight reseller
content:
As summer travel season gets underway, Canadians no doubt will be scanning the skies for bargain-priced flights. 
Some may have been expecting to fly with NewLeaf Travel, a Winnipeg-based startup that billed itself as an alternative to airlines like WestJet (TSX:WJA) and Air Canada (TSX:AC) when it launched in January to much public fanfare.
But a week after the company started selling tickets, it hit some turbulence over whether it needed a licence to operate.
NewLeaf suspended ticket sales and refunded flights it had scheduled for February as it awaited a ruling from the Canadian Transportation Agency.
The company contended that it did not require a licence because it is not an airline and doesn't operate airplanes. Instead, it purchases seats from Kelowna, B.C.-based Flair Airlines and resells them to the public. Flair Airlines, which owns and operates a fleet of Boeing 737-400 jets, is licensed under the CTA.
On March 30, the agency ruled in favour of NewLeaf and cleared the way for the company to resume ticket sales. At that time, NewLeaf CEO Jim Young said the company expected flights to take off in late spring or early summer.
Since then, there's been little movement from the company.
NewLeaf was planning to fly from:
Lisa Krishka, a spokeswoman for NewLeaf, said it still plans to begin travel this summer. She would not offer a specific restart date.
Canadian aviation experts say a number of reasons may be behind the lack of clarity on a relaunch.
On Thursday, the Federal Court of Appeal agreed to hear an appeal by air passenger rights advocate regarding whether the CTA has the authority to permit NewLeaf to operate without a licence.
At issue, according to Gabor Lukacs, is that other companies have operated under similar business models and have required licences.
He doesn't expect the court to hear the appeal until at least the fall, but urged that passengers need to be cautious while the case is still under review.
The court did not say whether NewLeaf would have to put off its relaunch until the hearing. The company did not respond to a request for comment late Thursday after the court's decision.
But Robert Kokonis, president at aerospace consultancy AirTrav Inc., suspects NewLeaf may be trying to beef up investment before they launch again.
"The airline business is a cash-intensive business," he said. 
Kokonis said there is demand for discount carriers in Canada where base fares are low but any add-ons, from luggage to seat selection, are considered extras and come with accompanying fees.
"(Canada) is the only major aviation market in the world that doesn't have an ultra-low cost carrier," he said, noting that a number of factors stay in the way.
"We have a very high cost structure, fees, charges, and taxes that scares away ultra-low cost carriers. The successful ultra-low cost carriers of the world in the U.S., in continental Europe and Asia, thrive on a very dense geographic area to offer flights. ... Canada is very dispersed with not a huge population."
Bruce Cran of the Consumers' Association of Canada said people should be wary when booking with new startups that operate under a new business models because they can be exempt from having to provide protections on baggage and cancelled flights afforded to passengers who directly book with established airlines.
"They should be cautious because this is something completely new that we've never had before in Canada," he said.

title: ACE Aviation buying aircraft maintenance unit of Grupo TACA
content:
ACE Aviation Holdings Inc. said Monday that one of its subsidiaries is buying an 80 per cent stake in the aircraft maintenance division of El Salvador's Grupo TACA Holdings Ltd.
The acquisition by ACE subsidiary ACTS LP is for $44.7 million US in cash plus the right to acquire an equity stake inACTS.
The exact size of the equity stake will be confirmed at a later date and is expected to be less than seven per cent of ACTS's total equity.
ACTSprovides aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaulsfor over 100 customers, including Air Canada, Delta Air Lines, the Department of National Defence of Canada, JetBlue and Air Transat.
"This acquisition is in line with ACE's strategy to generate shareholder value by furthering the development of ACTS as a stand-alone, profitable entity," said ACE chief executive Robert Milton.
The acquisition is expected to close during the first quarter of 2007.
